introduction.line: SvbScript (SVB) is a custom scripting language made to give access to all existing (plus some more advanced) capabilities of SilverBullet Pro.

Every instruction is a one-liner (but can be broken down into multiple segments for readability) and it will integrate the existing block execution capabilities with some other that cannot be reproduced with normal blocks.
This is ABSOLUTELY NOT a fully functional scripting language meant to replace the capabilities offered by JavaScript or Python.
Here's an example of a SvbScript command:
PRINT Hello, World!
And here's how you would execute a standard Function Block:
ConstantString "Hello, World!" -> VAR "GREETING"
In this documentation you will learn how to use SvbScript to its full potential and integrate it with your other blocks or even stop using blocks altogether!
You should use SvbScript when:
• you need more powerful tools to build a config
• you want something faster and much easier to debug at a glance
• you don't want to deal with clicking on tens of blocks in big configs

item.name: Introduction
item.introduction: SvbScript has a linear syntax where each line is a command.

introduction.line: Indentation will be considered as a continuation of the previous line, so writing something like:
ConstantString
"Hello, World!"
-> VAR "GREETING"
is completely equivalent to the one-liner above.
Optional arguments will be wrapped with square brackets [ ] and they don't need to be set each time.
Every command follows this scheme:
CMDID [ARGUMENTS]
CMDID uniquely identifies a command or flow control statement by its name
[ARGUMENTS] can have different types and they are used to customize the command you want to execute

item.name: Argument Types
item.line: The arguments can be of 4 types:
• Boolean (a parameter name (case sensitive!) followed by =True or =False)
Note that you will have to escape double quotes inside a literal, for example
ConstantString "This is how to \"escape\" double quotes" ...
• Redirector (used to direct the output to a variable or a file)

item.name: Variables
item.line: You can access the saved values of variables and use them in literals by including them in angle brackets like this <A>.

examples.b: - List (access one element by index or all element using * as index)
- Dictionary (access by key using () and by value using {}, supports *)

item.name: Comments
item.introduction: Every line that starts with two #s is considered a comment

item.name: PRINT
item.introduction: This command is peculiar since it doesn't take a literal argument but just parses the rest of the line after the keyword PRINT and outputs it to the debugger log.
item.example:
PRINT "Hello, World"
PRINT "Hello, World" White
PRINT "Hello, World" "#fbec5d"
PRINT "Hello, World" "255,200,90"

item.name: SET
item.introduction: This command is very powerful as it allows manipulation on the global data of the bot.

identifiers.identifier: SOURCE - The stored response source of the last request performed
STATUS - The status of the bot
RESPONSECODE - The response code of the last request performed
COOKIE - Sets the value for a cookie of the global cookie jar given its name
ADDRESS - The address of the response of the last request performed
USEPROXY - Whether to use the proxy that is currently assigned to the bot during requests
PROXYTYPE - Sets the current proxy type
NEWGVAR - Initializes a new global variable (only if it doesn't exist)
GVAR - Sets a global variable's value
GCOOKIES - Sets cookies from the local cookie jar into the global cookie jar

item.example: SET SOURCE "Example Source" SET RAWSOURCE "Example Src" SET STATUS SUCCESS SET STATUS CUSTOM "ABCD" SET RESPONSECODE 200 SET COOKIE "token" "abcdef" SET ADDRESS "https://www.google.com" SET USEPROXY FALSE SET PROXY "127.0.0.1:8888" SET PROXYTYPE HTTP SET DATA "abc:def" SET VAR "varname" "data" SET VAR "varname" "1" Integer SET CAP "capname" "data" SET CAP "capname" "1" Integer SET NEWGVAR "sharedcookie" "abc=123" SET NEWGVAR "sharedcookie" "123" Integer SET GVAR "sharedcookie" "def=456" SET GVAR "sharedcookie" "456" Integer SET GCOOKIES

item.name: SUM
item.introduction: This command calculates the sum of two numbers. If the second number (NUMBER2) is not provided, it defaults to 1.
item.example: SUM 5 3 -> VAR "result" SUM $"<num1>" 3 -> VAR "result" SUM 5 $"<num2>" -> VAR "result" SUM $"<num>" -> VAR "result" SUM $"<num>"

item.name: SUB
item.introduction: This command calculates the difference between two numbers. If the second number (NUMBER2) is not provided, it defaults to 1.
item.example: SUB 10 2 -> VAR "result" SUB $"<num1>" 2 -> VAR "result" SUB 10 $"<num2>" -> VAR "result" SUB $"<num>" -> VAR "result" SUB $"<num>"

item.name: MUL
item.introduction: This command multiplies two numbers. If the second number (NUMBER2) is not provided, it defaults to 1.
item.example: MUL 5 2 -> VAR "result" MUL $"<num1>" 2 -> VAR "result" MUL 5 $"<num2>" -> VAR "result" MUL $"<num>" -> VAR "result" MUL $"<num>"

item.name: DIV
item.introduction: This command divides one number by another. If the second number (NUMBER2) is not provided, it defaults to 1.
item.example: DIV 15 2 -> VAR "result" DIV 15 $"<num2>" -> VAR "result" DIV $"<num>" -> VAR "result" DIV $"<num>"

item.name: STOP
item.introduction: This command stops the bot execution.

item.name: FORCESTOP
item.introduction: This command forcefully stops the bot execution.

item.name: RETURN
item.introduction: This command returns from the bot execution.

item.name: DELETE
item.introduction: This command allows you to delete elements from current collections.
item.example: DELETE COOKIE Contains "phpsessid" DELETE VAR "TOKEN" DELETE GVAR "MAX"

notes.note: The default condition is EqualTo

item.name: Mouse Action
item.introduction: This command allows you to perform advanced mouse actions in the browser.

syntax.line: General Syntax for an ELEMENT parameter:

Actions.comment: ## Spawn a div with a given id to a (x,y) absolute position, so you can use it as element hook for mouse movement
## Draws random points in a square starting from the top left corner and with the given width and height

exmaple.comment: ## Moving to an element and clicking 100 pixels right of it
## Moving to a specific set of coordinates on the page
## Moving like a human from point A (0,0) to point B (700,700). The lower the AMOUNT, the faster the line is drawn
## Moving like a human from element with id="one" to element with id="two", 20 points and default gravity/wind

item.name: INPUT
item.description: The input data for the current bot task.

item.name: STATUS
item.description: The current status of the bot.

item.name: BOTNUM
item.description: The unique number of the bot.

item.name: RETRIES
item.description: The number of retries for the current task.

item.name: BASEDIR
item.description: The base directory of the application.

item.name: EXMSG
item.description: The last exception message encountered by the bot.

item.name: OCRRATE
item.description: The OCR rate or accuracy of the OCR process.

item.name: ISDEBUG
item.description: Indicates whether the bot is in debug mode.

item.name: PROXY
item.description: The full proxy string if a proxy is used.

item.name: PROXYHOST
item.description: The host of the proxy server.

item.name: PROXYPORT
item.description: The port number of the proxy server.

item.name: PROXYNEEDSAUTH
item.description: Indicates whether the proxy server requires authentication.

item.name: PROXYUSER
item.description: The username for proxy authentication. (Alternative to PROXYAUTHUSER)

item.name: PROXYPASS
item.description: The password for proxy authentication. (Alternative to PROXYAUTHPASS)

item.name: PROXYTYPE
item.description: The type of the proxy (e.g., HTTP, SOCKS5).

item.name: PROXYCOUNTRY
item.description: The country associated with the proxy server.

section.name: Block Commands

item.name: Info

introduction.line: Block commands allow you to initiate and execute specific blocks after setting the necessary parameters. Each block command corresponds to a specific type of block in the SilverBulletPro Core.
To label any block, use the `#` symbol followed by your desired label. This helps in organizing and identifying blocks in complex scripts. For example:
#GETLEN Length "Test123" -> VAR "LEN"
The "-> VAR/CAP" syntax at the end of a block command is used to specify the output variable or capture. "VAR" indicates a regular variable, while "CAP" denotes a capture.

item.b: For all blocks, when specifying inputs such as byte arrays, strings, or other data types, you can use various formats:

formats.format: - $"<Variable> Value...": Allows you to input variables as values.
- CS"code": Executes the provided c# code at runtime and uses its output.
- JS"script": Executes the provided javascript and uses its output.
- HEX"hexadecimal": Represents a value in hexadecimal format.
- B64"base64": Represents a value in base64 format.
- EXP"expression": Executes expressions or lambda functions and uses their output.

item.name: HttpRequest
item.introduction: This block is designed to perform HTTP requests and receive responses from servers. It offers the capability to send various HTTP requests, including methods like GET, POST, and other HTTP verbs.
item.syntax: HttpRequest [HttpLibrary] [HttpVersion] METHOD "URL" [AutoRedirect?] [ReadResponseSource?] [ParseQuery?] [EncodeContent?] [AlwaysSendContent?] [AppendResponseCookies?] [STANDARD / MULTIPART / BASICAUTH] [CONTENT "postdata"] [CONTENTTYPE "ctype"] [STRINGCONTENT "name:value"]* [FILECONTENT "name:path:content-type"]* [BOUNDARY "abcd"] [COOKIE "abc: def"]* [HEADER "abc: def"]* [SECPROTO security-protocol] [MAXREDIRECTS 8] [TIMEOUT 15000] [PROXY Default] [SAFE?] [-> STRING / -> FILE "path" / -> BASE64 "VARNAME"]

parameters.parameter: - [HttpLibrary]: Specifies the library to use for the HTTP request.
- [HttpVersion]: Specifies the HTTP version for the request (e.g., HTTP/1.1, HTTP/2).
- METHOD: The HTTP method to use (e.g., GET, POST).
- "URL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The target URL for the HTTP request.
- [AutoRedirect?]: Determines if redirections by the server should be followed.
- [ReadResponseSource?]: If enabled, reads the server's response source.
- [ParseQuery?]: Processes the URL parameters.
- [EncodeContent?]: Determines if the sent content should be encoded.
- [AlwaysSendContent?]: Determines whether the content should always be sent with the request, regardless of the HTTP method used.
- [AppendResponseCookies?]: Determines if cookies from the HTTP response should be added to the current collection. Accepts 'True' or 'False'.
- [HEADER] "name: value": Adds a custom header to the request. Repeatable for multiple headers.
- [COOKIE] "name: value": Adds a custom cookie to the request. Repeatable for multiple cookies.
- [CONTENT] "postdata" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc: The data to be sent in the request body, typically used with POST requests.
- [CONTENTTYPE] "ctype": Specifies the MIME type of the request content (e.g., 'application/json').
- [STRINGCONTENT] "name:value": String content for multipart requests.
- [FILECONTENT] "name:path:content-type": File content for multipart requests.
- [BOUNDARY] "abcd": The boundary string used for separating parts in multipart requests.
- [SECPROTO]: Specifies the security protocol(s) to use for the HTTPS request.
- [PROXY]: Determines the method of using a proxy for sending HTTP requests.
- [TIMEOUT]: Specifies the timeout duration for the HTTP request in milliseconds.
- [MAXREDIRECTS]: Sets the maximum number of redirects allowed for the HTTP request.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example:
HttpRequest GET "http://example.com/file.zip" -> FILE "file.zip"
HttpRequest POST "http://example.com/poster" AutoRedirect=False COOKIE "Hello: World" HEADER "Hello: World" CONTENT "{"id":1}" CONTENTTYPE "application/json"
HttpRequest POST "http://example.com/multi" MULTIPART STRINGCONTENT "Hello: World" STRINGCONTENT "Hi: Again" FILECONTENT "Image: image.jpg" BOUNDARY "abcd"
HttpRequest GET "http://example.com/basic" BASICAUTH
HttpRequest 1.1 GET "http://example.com/"
HttpRequest Default 2.0 GET "http://example.com/"

notes.note: Ensure all parameters and settings are correctly specified when using the HttpRequest block. Incorrect settings may result in errors or unexpected results.

item.name: FtpConnect
item.introduction: The 'FtpConnect' block is used to create a connection to an FTP server, allowing for detailed configuration of connection parameters including host, port, timeout, and various SSL/TLS settings for secure communication.
item.syntax: FtpConnect "HOST" PORT TIMEOUT [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"] [SSL_MODE MODE] [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES CURVES] [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES SUITES] [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS VERSIONS] [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?] [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?] [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"host" / etc.: The hostname or IP address of the FTP server.
- PORT: The port number for the FTP connection (default is 21).
- TIMEOUT: The timeout for the connection in milliseconds.
- [SSL_MODE]: Sets the SSL mode (e.g., 'Explicit' or 'Implicit').
- [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES]: Specifies the allowed SSL elliptic curves.
- [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES]: Defines the allowed SSL cipher suites.
- [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS]: Determines the allowed SSL/TLS versions.
- [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?]: Allows the use of vulnerable SSL suites.
- [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?]: Accepts all SSL certificates without validation.
- Specifies the variable name where the connection state will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices.

item.example:
FtpConnect "ftp.example.com" $"<port>" 1000
FtpConnect "ftp.secure.com" 22 2000 SSL_MODE Explicit SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5 SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS SSL30 SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES
FtpConnect $"<ftp>" $"<port>" 2000 SSL_MODE Explicit SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS SSL30 SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES

notes.note: The 'FtpConnect' block is crucial for applications requiring secure and reliable FTP connections.
It's important to configure SSL/TLS settings carefully, especially for sensitive data transfer.
For best security practices, avoid using vulnerable suites and uncertified certificates unless absolutely necessary.

item.name: FtpLogin
item.introduction: The `FtpLogin` block is designed for authenticating a user to an FTP server. It enables the user to establish a connection with the server using a username and password.

parameters.parameter: - "USERNAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The username used for authentication. Can be a string, a variable, or a script output.
- "PASSWORD" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The password associated with the username. Can be a string, a variable, or a script output.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Optionally, specifies the variable name to store the authentication result. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure that the FTP server is accessible and that the provided credentials are correct. Incorrect credentials or unreachable servers will result in authentication failure.

item.name: FtpDisconnect
item.introduction: The `FtpDisconnect` block is used to disconnect from a currently connected FTP server. This is useful for cleanly ending a session and ensuring resources are released properly.

parameters.parameter: - [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Optionally, specifies the variable name to store the response from the disconnect operation. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, such as handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: It is important to disconnect from the FTP server when the session is no longer needed to free up resources and avoid potential issues with too many open connections.

item.name: FtpDownloadFile
item.introduction: The `FtpDownloadFile` block is used to download a file from an FTP server. It allows specifying both the remote file path on the FTP server and the local path where the file should be saved, along with other options like file mode and download speed limits.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path of the file on the FTP server to be downloaded.
- "LOCALPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The local path where the downloaded file will be saved.
- [FileMode]: Specifies the file mode used when writing the file locally, such as 'Create', 'Append', etc.
- [MaxDownloadSpeed / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Specifies the maximum download speed in bytes per second. If not set, no limit will be applied.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure the remote file path and local path are correct. Incorrect paths or inaccessible directories will result in download failure.

item.name: FtpUploadFile
item.introduction: The `FtpUploadFile` block is used to upload a file to an FTP server. It allows specifying both the local file path to be uploaded and the remote path on the FTP server where the file should be saved, along with other options like file mode and upload speed limits.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path on the FTP server where the file will be uploaded.
- "LOCALPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The local file path of the file to be uploaded.
- [FileMode]: Specifies the file mode used when opening the file locally, such as 'Open', 'Create', etc.
- [MaxUploadSpeed / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Specifies the maximum upload speed in bytes per second. If not set, no limit will be applied.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure the local file path and remote path are correct. Incorrect paths or inaccessible files will result in upload failure.

item.name: FtpUpload
item.introduction: The `FtpUpload` block is used to upload a local file or directory hierarchy to a specified directory on the FTP server. This block is versatile, supporting various options like traversal modes, transfer methods, actions on existing files, and upload speed limits.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEDIRPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path of the directory on the FTP server where the file or directory will be uploaded.
- "LOCALDIRPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The local directory path of the file or directory to be uploaded.
- [TraversalMode]: Specifies the traversal mode for directory upload, such as 'Recursive' or 'NonRecursive'.
- [TransferMethod]: Specifies the transfer method, like 'Copy' or 'Move'.
- [ActionOnExistingFiles]: Defines the action when existing files are encountered, such as 'OverwriteAll', 'Skip' or 'Rename'.
- [MaxUploadSpeed / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Specifies the maximum upload speed in bytes per second. If not set, no limit will be applied.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure the local directory path and remote directory path are correct. Incorrect paths or inaccessible files will result in upload failure.

item.name: FtpDownload
item.introduction: The `FtpDownload` block is used to download a specific file or directory hierarchy from the FTP server to a local directory. This block supports various options like traversal modes, transfer methods, actions on existing files, and download speed limits. It also accepts wildcards for file selection.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path of the file or directory on the FTP server to be downloaded.
- "LOCALDIRPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The local directory path where the downloaded file or directory will be saved.
- [TraversalMode]: Specifies the traversal mode for directory download, such as 'Recursive' or 'NonRecursive'.
- [TransferMethod]: Specifies the transfer method, like 'Copy' or 'Move'.
- [ActionOnExistingFiles]: Defines the action when existing files are encountered, such as 'OverwriteAll', 'Skip' or 'Rename'.
- [MaxDownloadSpeed / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Specifies the maximum download speed in bytes per second. If not set, no limit will be applied.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure the remote path and local directory path are correct. Incorrect paths or inaccessible files will result in download failure. Wildcards can be used to select multiple files for download.

item.name: FtpListItems
item.introduction: The `FtpListItems` block is used to list the folders and files on the FTP server. This block provides flexibility in specifying the types of items to list (such as files, directories, or links) and supports various filtering options.

parameters.parameter: - "ARGUMENTS" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The arguments or path used to filter the items listed. Can be a string, a variable, or a script output.
- IsFile: A boolean flag to list only files.
- [IsDirectory?]: A boolean flag to list only directories.
- [IsLink?]: A boolean flag to list only links.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": specifies the name of the variable to store the list of folders/files returned from the FTP server.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Use the appropriate arguments and flags to filter and list the desired files, directories, or links. This block can be used to efficiently navigate and manage files on an FTP server.

item.name: FtpGetFileLength
item.introduction: The `FtpGetFileLength` block is used to obtain the size of a specified file on the FTP server. This block can be particularly useful for determining the size of a remote file before downloading or processing it.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path of the file on the FTP server for which the size is to be retrieved.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": specifies the name of the variable to store the size of the file.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Make sure the specified file path is correct. Incorrect paths or inaccessible files will result in an error.

item.name: FtpFileExists
item.introduction: The `FtpFileExists` block is used to check whether a specific file exists on the FTP server. This function may not be supported by all FTP servers, so it's important to verify compatibility with your server.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path of the file on the FTP server to check for existence.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": specifies the name of the variable to store the result (true or false) indicating whether the file exists.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, like handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure the specified file path is correct. Incorrect paths or inaccessible files may result in false negatives.

item.name: FtpDeleteFile
item.introduction: The `FtpDeleteFile` block is designed to delete a specific file from the FTP server. It's essential for managing files on the server, allowing you to remove unwanted or obsolete files.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the path of the file on the FTP server to be deleted.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Optionally, specifies the name of the variable to store the operation result (true for successful deletion, false otherwise).
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure the file path is correct and the file exists on the server. Incorrect paths or non-existent files may lead to exceptions or false negatives.

item.name: FtpDelete
item.introduction: The `FtpDelete` block is used to delete specified files and/or directories from an FTP server. It offers flexibility in managing server contents, especially for bulk deletions or complex file structures.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the path of the file or directory on the FTP server to be deleted. Can be a specific path or a pattern matching multiple files/directories.
- [TraversalMode]: Optional parameter to specify the deletion mode. 'NonRecursive' for a single file or directory, 'Recursive' to include all subdirectories and files.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Optionally, specifies the name of the variable to store the operation result (true for successful deletion, false otherwise).
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Use caution with the 'Recursive' mode as it will delete all contents within the specified directory, including subdirectories and their files.

item.name: FtpChangeDir
item.introduction: The `FtpChangeDir` block is used to change the current working directory on an FTP server. This is crucial for navigating through the server's directory structure and performing operations in different directories.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the directory path on the FTP server to which the working directory should be changed.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Optionally, specifies the name of the variable to store the operation result (true if the directory change was successful, false otherwise).
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Ensure that the directory path is correct and exists on the server. Incorrect paths may lead to errors or unsuccessful operations.

item.name: FtpGetCurrentDir
item.introduction: The `FtpGetCurrentDir` block is used to retrieve the absolute path of the current working directory on an FTP server. This is useful for understanding the server's directory structure and confirming the current directory context.

parameters.parameter: - [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies the name of the variable where the current directory path will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: Knowing the current directory can be vital for subsequent FTP operations, such as file uploading or downloading.

item.name: FtpGetFileDateTime
item.introduction: The `FtpGetFileDateTime` block is used to retrieve the modification date and time of a specified file on an FTP server. This can be crucial for tracking changes, version control, or simply understanding the timeline of file updates.

parameters.parameter: - "REMOTEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code": The path of the file on the FTP server whose date and time you want to retrieve.
- ["DateTimeFormat"]: Optional format string to specify the output format of the date and time. The default format is 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.fffffffK'.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies the name of the variable where the retrieved date and time will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: An optional parameter that, when included, ensures the block's execution adheres to safe practices, handling exceptions gracefully.

notes.note: This block is particularly useful in scenarios where file integrity and change tracking are critical.

item.name: FtpGetConnectionState
item.introduction: The `FtpGetConnectionState` block is used to check the current state of the FTP session, verifying if it is still connected. Additionally, it can return the native error code of the connection state.

parameters.parameter: - [GETERRORCODE?]: An optional parameter. When set to 'true', the block will return the native error code along with the connection state.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the connection state will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It is essential to first establish a connection with the FTP server using the appropriate FTP connection blocks before using this block to check the connection state.

item.name: FtpSendCommand
item.introduction: The `FtpSendCommand` block allows the execution of a specific command on the FTP server. This block can be used for a variety of server-specific commands, like requesting server help or status.

parameters.parameter: - "COMMAND" / $"variable" / CS"code": The command to be executed on the FTP server. It can be a direct command string, a variable, or a code snippet.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Before using this block, ensure that a connection to the FTP server is already established. Also, be aware of the specific commands supported by your FTP server.

item.name: FtpReadResponse
item.introduction: The `FtpReadResponse` block is designed to read and interpret the response of the FTP server to a previously executed command. This block provides options to read various aspects of the response, such as raw data, description, group, and code.

parameters.parameter: - [ReadRaw?]: Optional. If set, reads the raw response from the server.
- [ReadDescription?]: Optional. If set, reads the descriptive part of the response.
- [ReadGroup?]: Optional. If set, reads the response's group identifier.
- [ReadCode?]: Optional. If set, reads the response's code.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the response will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that a connection to the FTP server is established before using this block. The block is useful for debugging or understanding the server's responses to various commands.

item.name: ImapConnect
item.introduction: The `ImapConnect` block establishes a connection to an IMAP server. It supports various SSL/TLS configurations for secure email interactions.
item.syntax: ImapConnect "HOST" PORT TIMEOUT [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"] [SSL_MODE Mode] [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES CurveName] [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES SuiteName] [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS Version] [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?] [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?] [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The IMAP server address.
- PORT: The port number for the IMAP server.
- TIMEOUT: Connection timeout in milliseconds.
- [SSL_MODE]: The mode of SSL to use (e.g., Explicit, Implicit).
- [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES]: Specifies allowed SSL curves (e.g., NistP521, SecP256r1).
- [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES]: Defines the allowed SSL cipher suites (e.g., RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA, RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5).
- [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS]: Specifies allowed versions of SSL/TLS (e.g., TLS12, TLS10).
- [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?]: If set, allows vulnerable SSL suites.
- [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?]: If true, accepts all SSL certificates regardless of their validity.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies the variable name where the connection state will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example: ImapConnect "imap.example.com" 993 10000 -> VAR "IMAP_RESULT" SSL_MODE Explicit SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES

notes.note: It is crucial to provide accurate configurations for a secure connection. Improper SSL/TLS settings can compromise security.

item.name: ImapLogin
item.introduction: The `ImapLogin` block is used for logging into an IMAP account. It offers both standard authentication with username and password and token-based authentication.

parameters.parameter: - [METHOD]: The method of login (Account/Token). Defaults to Account if not specified.
- ["USERNAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The username for login. Required if METHOD is Account.
- ["PASSWORD" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The password for login. Required if METHOD is Account.
- ["TOKEN" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The token for login. Required if METHOD is Token.
- [AUTHMETHOD]: The authentication method to use (e.g., Auto, Plain).
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies the variable name where the login result will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure to use secure and encrypted methods for storing and transmitting login credentials. Avoid logging sensitive information in an insecure manner.

item.name: ImapDisconnect
item.introduction: The `ImapDisconnect` block is used for disconnecting from an IMAP server. It ensures that the session is properly closed and the resources are freed.

parameters.parameter: - [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies the variable name where the disconnection status will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It is recommended to always disconnect properly from the server to avoid any potential resource leaks or session issues.

item.name: ImapReadMail
item.introduction: The `ImapReadMail` block retrieves the text or HTML representation of an email from an IMAP server. It provides the flexibility to prefer HTML content if available.

parameters.parameter: - "UNIQUEID" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier of the email message to retrieve.
- [PreferHtml?]: Specifies whether to prefer retrieving the HTML content of the email. Set to 'True' to prefer HTML, and 'False' or omit for default text content.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the email content will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the correct email identifier is used to fetch the appropriate email. Be cautious when handling HTML content to avoid security risks.

item.name: ImapReadMailRaw
item.introduction: The `ImapReadMailRaw` block retrieves an email in EML format from an IMAP server. This is useful for obtaining the complete raw data of the email.

parameters.parameter: - "UNIQUEID" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier of the email message to retrieve.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the raw EML data of the email will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Handling raw EML data requires appropriate parsing capabilities. Ensure that the unique identifier corresponds to the correct email message.

item.name: ImapSearchMails
item.introduction: The `ImapSearchMails` block searches for emails on an IMAP server based on various criteria such as sender, subject, body content, and specific keywords.

parameters.parameter: - "FROM" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The email address of the sender to filter the search.
- "SUBJECT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The subject of the email to filter the search.
- "ARRIVED" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The date when the email arrived to filter the search.
- ["BODY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The content of the email body to filter the search.
- "KEYWORD" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specific keywords to look for in the emails.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the search results will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Use specific and relevant criteria for effective search results. Ensure that the search parameters are well-defined to retrieve the desired emails.

item.name: ImapCreateFolder
item.introduction: The `ImapCreateFolder` block is used to create a new folder on an IMAP server. It allows for organizing emails by categorizing them into different folders.

parameters.parameter: - "FOLDER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The name of the new folder to be created on the IMAP server.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the folder name does not conflict with existing folder names on the server. Use a unique and descriptive name for easy identification.

item.name: ImapSelectFolder
item.introduction: The `ImapSelectFolder` block selects a specific folder on an IMAP server, enabling access to the messages within that folder.

parameters.parameter: - "FOLDER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The name of the folder to be selected on the IMAP server.
- [ReadOnly?]: Optional. Specifies whether the folder should be opened in read-only mode. Set to 'True' to open the folder as read-only, and 'False' or omit for standard access.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Choosing the correct folder is crucial for processing the intended emails. Ensure that the folder exists on the server before selecting it.

item.name: ImapDeleteFolder
item.introduction: The `ImapDeleteFolder` block is used to delete a folder on an IMAP server. It is important for managing and organizing the mailbox structure effectively.

parameters.parameter: - "FOLDER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The name of the folder to be deleted from the IMAP server.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Be cautious when deleting folders, as this action cannot be undone. Ensure that the correct folder name is specified to avoid accidental deletion of important data.

item.name: ImapUnselectFolder
item.introduction: The `ImapUnselectFolder` block is used to unselect the currently selected folder on an IMAP server. This is useful for releasing resources or changing focus to a different folder.

parameters.parameter: - [PurgeDeleted?]: Optional. Specifies whether to purge (permanently remove) all messages marked as deleted. Set to 'True' to purge deleted messages, and 'False' or omit to retain them.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Use this block carefully, especially with the PURGE_DELETED option, as it may result in the permanent removal of deleted messages.

item.name: ImapRenameFolder
item.introduction: The `ImapRenameFolder` block is used to rename an existing folder on an IMap server. It helps in organizing and managing the mailbox structure more efficiently.

parameters.parameter: - "CURRENTFOLDERNAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The current name of the folder to be renamed.
- "NEWFOLDERNAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The new name for the folder.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the new folder name is unique and does not conflict with existing folder names. The renaming of folders helps in better mailbox management and organization.

item.name: ImapDeleteMail
item.introduction: The `ImapDeleteMail` block is used to delete an email from an IMAP server. This block allows you to permanently remove specific emails by their unique identifier.

parameters.parameter: - ID / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier of the email to be deleted.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Use caution when deleting emails, as this action is irreversible. Ensure the correct email ID is used to prevent accidental deletions.

item.name: ImapGetSupportedAuthMethods
item.introduction: The `ImapGetSupportedAuthMethods` block retrieves the list of supported authentication methods from an IMAP server. It's useful for identifying the available security mechanisms for connecting to the server.

parameters.parameter: - -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the list of supported authentication methods will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Understanding the supported authentication methods is crucial for configuring secure and compatible connections to the IMAP server.

item.name: ImapSendCommand
item.introduction: The `ImapSendCommand` block executes a custom command on the IMAP server. This allows for advanced operations and interactions with the server outside of standard email actions.

parameters.parameter: - "COMMAND" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The command to be executed on the IMAP server. Commands should be IMAP server-specific.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the command syntax is correct and compatible with the IMAP server. Incorrect commands may lead to unexpected responses or errors.

item.name: ImapReadResponse
item.introduction: The `ImapReadResponse` block is used to read and interpret the response from the IMAP server after executing a command. It helps in understanding the outcome of the command sent to the server.

parameters.parameter: - [ReadDescription?]: Optional. Specifies whether to read and store the description part of the IMAP server's response. Set to 'True' to include the description, 'False' or omit for no description.
- [ReadCode?]: Optional. Specifies whether to read and store the code part of the IMAP server's response. Set to 'True' to include the code, 'False' or omit for no code.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the name of the variable where the response data will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example:
ImapReadResponse ReadDescription=True ReadCode=True -> VAR "SERVER_RESPONSE"
ImapReadResponse -> VAR "SERVER_RESPONSE"

notes.note: Understanding the server's response is crucial for debugging and managing IMAP interactions. Ensure that the command sent to the server is valid and expects a response.

item.name: SmtpConnect
item.introduction: The `SmtpConnect` block is used to establish a connection to an SMTP server. This block is essential for sending emails and managing email-related tasks via the SMTP protocol.
item.syntax: SmtpConnect "HOST" PORT TIMEOUT [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"] [SSL_MODE MODE] [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES CURVES] [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES SUITES] [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS VERSIONS] [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?] [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?] [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The address of the SMTP server.
- PORT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The port number to connect to on the SMTP server.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The timeout for the connection in milliseconds.
- [SSL_MODE]: Optional. The SSL mode to use for the connection.
- [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES]: Optional. Specifies allowed SSL elliptic curves.
- [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES]: Optional. Defines the allowed SSL cipher suites.
- [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS]: Optional. Specifies allowed versions of SSL/TLS.
- [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?]: Optional. Allows vulnerable SSL suites if set.
- [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?]: Optional. Accepts all SSL certificates if set.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies the name of the variable where the connection status will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example:
SmtpConnect "smtp.example.com" 587 10000 -> VAR "CONNECTION_STATUS" SSL_MODE Explicit SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES
SmtpConnect "smtp.example.com" $"<port>" $"<timeout>" SSL_MODE Explicit

notes.note: Ensure correct SMTP server details are provided. SSL/TLS settings should be configured according to the server's requirements for secure communication.

item.name: SmtpLogin
item.introduction: The `SmtpLogin` block is designed for logging into an SMTP server. It supports both standard authentication with username and password and token-based authentication.

parameters.parameter: - [METHOD]: The method of login (Account/Token). Defaults to Account if not specified.
- ["USERNAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The username for login. Required if METHOD is Account.
- ["PASSWORD" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The password for login. Required if METHOD is Account.
- ["TOKEN" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The token for login. Required if METHOD is Token.
- [AuthMethod]: The authentication method to use (e.g., Auto, Plain).
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies the variable name where the login result will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure to use secure and encrypted methods for storing and transmitting login credentials. Avoid logging sensitive information in an insecure manner.

item.name: SmtpDisconnect
item.introduction: The `SmtpDisconnect` block is used to disconnect from an SMTP server, terminating the current session and releasing resources.

parameters.parameter: - [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Optional. Specifies the variable name where the disconnect result will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.

notes.note: Use this block when you have completed all required SMTP interactions to properly close the connection.

item.name: SmtpSendMail
item.introduction: The `SmtpSendMail` block is used to send an email to a recipient(s) through an SMTP server. It supports sending both text and HTML-based emails.

parameters.parameter: - "SENDER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The email address of the sender.
- "RECIPIENTS" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The email address(es) of the recipient(s).
- SUBJECT "Subject" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The subject line of the email.
- TEXT_BODY "Text" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The plain text content of the email.
- HTML_BODY "Html" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The HTML content of the email.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example:
SmtpSendMail "sender@example.com" "recipient@example.com" SUBJECT "Greetings" TEXT_BODY "This is a plain text message" HTML_BODY "

This is an HTML message

"

notes.note: Ensure that the SMTP client is connected before using this block. Check and handle any errors that may occur during the sending process.

item.name: SmtpGetSupportedAuthMethods
item.introduction: The `SmtpGetSupportedAuthMethods` block is used to retrieve a list of authentication methods supported by an SMTP server.

parameters.parameter: - -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Optional. Specifies the variable name where the list of supported authentication methods will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable will be captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Knowing the supported authentication methods is crucial for configuring secure and compatible email interactions with the SMTP server.

item.name: SmtpSendCommand
item.introduction: The `SmtpSendCommand` block is used for executing specific commands on an SMTP server, such as "HELP" or other server-specific commands.

parameters.parameter: - "COMMAND" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The command to be sent to the SMTP server.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It is important to be familiar with the SMTP server's command syntax and capabilities. Improper commands may lead to unexpected responses or errors.

item.name: SmtpReadResponse
item.introduction: The `SmtpReadResponse` block reads and interprets the response of the SMTP server. It can extract and analyze different elements of the response, providing detailed insights into the server's feedback.

parameters.parameter: - [ReadRaw?]: Optional. Extracts the full unparsed response from the SMTP server.
- [ReadDescription?]: Optional. Retrieves the description part of the SMTP response.
- [ReadGroup?]: Optional. Identifies the group category of the SMTP response code.
- [ReadCode?]: Optional. Extracts the SMTP response code.
- [IsSuccessful?]: Optional. Returns true if the last command was completed successfully by the SMTP server.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Designates the variable name where the response information will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Understanding SMTP server responses is essential for the effective use of this block, especially in complex email operations.

item.name: Pop3Connect
item.introduction: The `Pop3Connect` block is designed to establish a connection with a POP3 server, supporting various SSL/TLS configurations for secure email retrieval.
item.syntax: Pop3Connect "HOST" PORT TIMEOUT [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"] [SSL_MODE Mode] [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES CurveName] [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES SuiteName] [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS Version] [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?] [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?] [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The POP3 server address.
- PORT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The port number for the POP3 server.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Connection timeout in milliseconds.
- [SSL_MODE]: Specifies the SSL mode to be used (e.g., Implicit, Explicit).
- [SSL_ALLOWED_CURVES]: Specifies allowed SSL curves for encryption (e.g., NistP521, SecP256r1).
- [SSL_ALLOWED_SUITES]: Defines the allowed SSL cipher suites (e.g., RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA, RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5).
- [SSL_ALLOWED_VERSIONS]: Specifies allowed versions of SSL/TLS (e.g., TLS12, TLS10).
- [SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES?]: If set, allows use of vulnerable SSL suites.
- [SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES?]: If true, accepts all SSL certificates, regardless of their validity.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Designates the variable name where the connection result will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example: Pop3Connect "pop3.example.com" 110 10000 -> VAR "POP3_RESULT" SSL_MODE Explicit SSL_ALLOW_VULNERABLE_SUITES SSL_ACCEPT_ALL_CERTIFICATES

notes.note: It is crucial to use accurate configurations for a secure connection. Improper SSL/TLS settings can lead to security vulnerabilities.

item.name: Pop3Login
item.introduction: The `Pop3Login` block enables logging into a POP3 account, offering both username/password and token-based authentication methods.

parameters.parameter: - [METHOD]: The method of login (Account/Token). Account is the default method if not specified.
- "USERNAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The username for account-based login. Required if METHOD is Account.
- "PASSWORD" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The password for account-based login. Required if METHOD is Account.
- "TOKEN" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The token for token-based login. Required if METHOD is Token.
- [AUTHMETHOD]: Specifies the authentication method to be used (e.g., Auto, Plain).
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Determines the variable name where the login result will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure secure handling and transmission of login credentials. Avoid exposing sensitive information in insecure environments.

item.name: Pop3Disconnect
item.introduction: The `Pop3Disconnect` block is used to disconnect from a POP3 server. This block ensures that the connection is safely terminated.

parameters.parameter: - [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: If specified, stores the response of the disconnect operation in a variable. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for further use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It's important to disconnect properly to free up resources and ensure clean termination of the session.

item.name: Pop3GetMails
item.introduction: The `Pop3GetMails` block is used for retrieving a list of all emails from a POP3 server. It lists emails in the format From|To|Subject, from the newest to the oldest.

parameters.parameter: - MAXAMOUNT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The maximum number of emails to retrieve. If set to 0, all emails will be retrieved.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name to store the list of emails. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the POP3 client is connected before using this block. The order of emails is from newest to oldest.

item.name: Pop3ReadMail
item.introduction: The `Pop3ReadMail` block retrieves a text (or HTML) representation of an email at a specified index from a POP3 server.

parameters.parameter: - INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the index of the email to read.
- [PreferHtml?]: If set to true, retrieves the HTML version of the email if available.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Designates the variable name where the email's details will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the POP3 client is connected before using this block. The email index is counted from the most recent email backwards.

item.name: Pop3GetSupportedAuthMethods
item.introduction: The `Pop3GetSupportedAuthMethods` block retrieves a list of authentication methods supported by a POP3 server.

parameters.parameter: - -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the list of supported authentication methods will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the POP3 client is connected before using this block to retrieve the supported authentication methods.

item.name: Pop3DeleteMail
item.introduction: The `Pop3DeleteMail` block is used for deleting an email from a POP3 server at a specified index.

parameters.parameter: - INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the email to delete on the POP3 server.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the POP3 client is connected before using this block. The email index is counted from the most recent email backwards.

item.name: Pop3SendCommand
item.introduction: The `Pop3SendCommand` block is used to execute a custom command on a POP3 server.

parameters.parameter: - "COMMAND" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The command to be executed on the POP3 server.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the POP3 client is connected before using this block. Use valid POP3 commands as specified by the server.

item.name: Pop3ReadResponse
item.introduction: The `Pop3ReadResponse` block reads the response of the POP3 server to the previously sent command.

parameters.parameter: - -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name where the server's response will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the POP3 client is connected and a command has been sent before using this block to read the response.

item.name: SshAuthenticateWithNone
item.introduction: The `SshAuthenticateWithNone` block logs in via SSH with no credentials, typically used for SSH connections where authentication is handled through other means.
item.syntax: SshAuthenticateWithNone "HOST" PORT TIMEOUT CHANNELTIMEOUT RETRYATTEMPTS USERNAME "user" [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The address of the SSH server.
- PORT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The port number for the SSH server.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Connection timeout in milliseconds.
- CHANNELTIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Timeout for SSH channel operations in milliseconds.
- RETRYATTEMPTS / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The number of retry attempts for the SSH connection.
- USERNAME ["user" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The username for the SSH connection.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Use this block carefully as it does not require authentication credentials. Ensure the server is configured to handle such connections securely.

item.name: SshAuthenticateWithPassword
item.introduction: The `SshAuthenticateWithPassword` block logs in via SSH using specified username and password credentials.
item.syntax: SshAuthenticateWithPassword "HOST" PORT TIMEOUT CHANNELTIMEOUT RETRYATTEMPTS USERNAME "user" PASSWORD "pass" [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The address of the SSH server.
- PORT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The port number for the SSH server.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Connection timeout in milliseconds.
- CHANNELTIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Timeout for SSH channel operations in milliseconds.
- RETRYATTEMPTS / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The number of retry attempts for the SSH connection.
- USERNAME ["user" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The username for the SSH connection.
- PASSWORD ["pass" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The password for the SSH connection.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the provided username and password are correct for the SSH server. Incorrect credentials can lead to failed authentication attempts.

item.name: SshAuthenticateWithPK
item.introduction: The `SshAuthenticateWithPK` block logs in via SSH using a private key stored in a specified file.
item.syntax: SshAuthenticateWithPK "HOST" PORT TIMEOUT CHANNELTIMEOUT RETRYATTEMPTS USERNAME "user" KFILE "keyfile" KFPASS "keyfilepass" [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The address of the SSH server.
- PORT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The port number for the SSH server.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Connection timeout in milliseconds.
- CHANNELTIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Timeout for SSH channel operations in milliseconds.
- RETRYATTEMPTS / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The number of retry attempts for the SSH connection.
- USERNAME ["user" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The username for the SSH connection.
- KFILE ["keyfile" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The path to the private key file used for authentication.
- KFPASS ["keyfilepass" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The passphrase for the private key file, if applicable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the private key file is secure and the passphrase is correctly provided if required.

item.name: SshDisconnect
item.introduction: The `SshDisconnect` block is used to disconnect the client from an SSH server, terminating the current session.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that any necessary operations or communications are completed before disconnecting from the SSH server.

item.name: SshRunCommand
item.introduction: The `SshRunCommand` block executes a specified command via an SSH connection and retrieves the output.

parameters.parameter: - "COMMAND" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The command to be executed on the SSH server.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name to store the command's output. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the SSH client is connected before executing a command. The command's output will include any standard output or errors.

item.name: TcpConnect
item.introduction: The `TcpConnect` block establishes a TCP connection with a given server, with options for SSL and custom timeouts.

parameters.parameter: - "HOST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The address of the TCP server.
- PORT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The port number for the TCP connection.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Connection timeout in milliseconds.
- [UseSSL?]: Specifies whether to use SSL for the connection.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the server supports the specified port and SSL settings. Use the proper timeout to balance responsiveness with network conditions.

item.name: TcpDisconnect
item.introduction: The `TcpDisconnect` block is used to close a previously opened socket, terminating the TCP connection.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure all necessary data transmission is complete before disconnecting the TCP connection.

item.name: TcpRead
item.introduction: The `TcpRead` block reads a specified number of bytes from a previously established TCP connection, decoding the data according to the specified character set.

parameters.parameter: - BYTESTOREAD / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The number of bytes to read from the TCP connection.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The timeout for the read operation in milliseconds.
- [CHARSET_OUT "encoding"]: The character set to use for decoding the bytes read. Default is ASCII.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name to store the received data. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the TCP connection is open and stable before attempting to read data. Adjust the number of bytes and timeout according to the expected data size and network conditions.

item.name: TcpSend
item.introduction: The `TcpSend` block sends a specified message over an established TCP connection, with options for message formatting and encoding.

parameters.parameter: - "MESSAGE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The message to be sent over the TCP connection.
- [CHARSET_MSG "encoding"]: The character set to use for encoding the message. Default is ASCII.
- [Unescape?]: Specifies whether to unescape special characters in the message.
- [TerminateWithCRLF?]: Specifies whether to terminate the message with a carriage return and line feed.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the TCP connection is open before sending a message. Adjust the message encoding and formatting to suit the server's requirements.

item.name: TcpSendRead
item.introduction: The `TcpSendRead` block sends a message through a TCP socket and immediately reads the response, allowing for interactive communication with the server.

parameters.parameter: - "MESSAGE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The message to be sent over the TCP connection.
- BYTES_TO_READ / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The number of bytes to read from the response.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The timeout for the read operation in milliseconds.
- [CHARSET_MSG "encoding"]: The character set to use for encoding the sent message. Default is ASCII.
- [CHARSET_OUT "encoding"]: The character set to use for decoding the received message. Default is ASCII.
- [Unescape?]: Specifies whether to unescape special characters in the sent message.
- [TerminateWithCRLF?]: Specifies whether to terminate the sent message with a carriage return and line feed.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name to store the received response. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the TCP connection is open before sending a message. Adjust the byte count and timeout to suit the expected response size and network conditions.

item.name: TcpSendReadHttp
item.introduction: The `TcpSendReadHttp` block sends an HTTP message over a TCP connection and reads the response, ideal for simple HTTP requests over TCP.

parameters.parameter: - "MESSAGE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The HTTP message to be sent over the TCP connection.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The timeout for the read operation in milliseconds.
- [CHARSET_MSG "encoding"]: The character set to use for encoding the sent message. Default is ASCII.
- [CHARSET_OUT "encoding"]: The character set to use for decoding the received response. Default is UTF-8.
- [Unescape?]: Specifies whether to unescape special characters in the sent message.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name to store the received response. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example:
TcpSendReadHttp "GET /index.html HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com

" 5000 -> VAR "HTTP_RESPONSE" CHARSET_MSG "UTF-8" CHARSET_OUT "UTF-8"

notes.note: Use this block for simple HTTP requests where a full HTTP client is not required. Ensure the message is correctly formatted as an HTTP request.

item.name: WebSocketConnect
item.introduction: The `WebSocketConnect` block establishes a connection to a WebSocket server, providing options for custom headers, cookies, and authentication.

parameters.parameter: - "URL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the WebSocket server.
- KEEPALIVETIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Keep-alive timeout in milliseconds for the WebSocket connection.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Connection timeout in milliseconds.
- [USERNAME "user" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Optional username for authentication.
- [PASSWORD "password" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Optional password for authentication.
- [COOKIE "name:value" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Custom cookie to send with the WebSocket connection request.
- [HEADER "key: value" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Custom header to send with the WebSocket connection request.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the WebSocket URL is correct and the server supports the specified protocols and authentication methods. Custom headers and cookies can be used for specific connection requirements.

item.name: WebSocketDisconnect
item.introduction: The `WebSocketDisconnect` block is used for disconnecting an already established WebSocket connection, ensuring the closure of the connection in a proper manner.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure any necessary data exchange or communication over the WebSocket is completed before initiating the disconnect.

item.name: WebSocketRead
item.introduction: The `WebSocketRead` block reads unread messages from a WebSocket connection, capturing the data for processing or display.

parameters.parameter: - BYTESTOREAD / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The number of bytes to read from the WebSocket message.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The timeout for the read operation in milliseconds. Use -1 for no timeout.
- [CHARSET_OUT "encoding"]: The character set to use for decoding the received message. Default is UTF-8.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Specifies the variable name to store the received data. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the WebSocket connection is open before reading messages. Adjust the byte count and timeout to suit the expected message size and network conditions.

item.name: WebSocketSend
item.introduction: The `WebSocketSend` block sends a message over an established WebSocket connection.

parameters.parameter: - "MESSAGE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The message to be sent over the WebSocket.
- [MESSAGETYPE]: Optional. Specifies the type of message (Text or Binary). Default is Text.
- [CHARSET_MSG "encoding"]: Optional. Specifies the encoding of the message. Default is ASCII.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that a WebSocket connection is established before using this block.
Message encoding can be crucial depending on the server requirements.

item.name: WebSocketSendAudio
item.introduction: The `WebSocketSendAudio` block is designed to send audio files over a WebSocket connection. This block allows for sending an opening message, the audio file, and a closing message.

parameters.parameter: - "OPENINGMESSAGE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: An optional message sent before the audio file.
- "AUDIOFILEPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path of the audio file to be sent.
- "CLOSINGMESSAGE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: An optional message sent after the audio file.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the WebSocket connection is established before sending audio. Audio files should be in a format supported by the server.

item.name: WebSocketClose
item.introduction: The `WebSocketClose` block is used to close an active WebSocket connection gracefully, providing an option to specify the closing status and a descriptive message.

parameters.parameter: - "STATUSDESCRIPTION" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The message describing the reason for closing the WebSocket.
- [WebSocketCloseStatus]: The status code representing the reason for closure, e.g., NormalClosure, EndpointUnavailable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure any necessary data exchange over the WebSocket is completed before initiating the closure. Select an appropriate close status for a clear understanding of the closure reason.

item.name: WebSocketState
item.introduction: The `WebSocketState` block retrieves the current state of a WebSocket connection, such as Connected, Disconnected, or Closed.

parameters.parameter: - -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable where the WebSocket state will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Useful for debugging and ensuring that the WebSocket is in the correct state before sending or receiving data.

item.name: Keycheck
item.introduction: This will spawn and execute a Keycheck Block. This block is utilized to validate a set of keys and modify the bot's status based on the outcome of the validation process.

parameters.parameter: - [BanOn4XX?]: Whether to set the bot status to BAN if the last HTTP code was of type 4.
- [BanOnToCheck?]: Whether to set the bot status as BAN if no keychain was valid.
- [FirstKeyFoundAndExit?]: Determines if the key checking process should stop after the first valid key is found, preventing further evaluations of subsequent KeyChains.
- TYPE ["CUSTOMNAME"]: Specifies the type of the keychain. Types include Success, Failure, Ban, Retry, Custom.
- MODE: The mode in which the keys should be checked. Modes include OR, AND.
- [PRIORITY]: Defines the execution priority for the KeyChain process. Priorities include Standard, Continue, Stop.
- KEY "STRING": The string to be checked in the keychain.
- [CONDITION "STRING"]: The condition to be applied on the key.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example: KeyCheck BanOnToCheck=False KEYCHAIN SUCCESS OR Standard KEY "Logout" KEYCHAIN FAILURE OR KEY $"<SOURCE>" EqualTo "" KEYCHAIN CUSTOM "DEFAULT" OR KEY "abc" Contains "ab"

notes.note: - As shown above, for brevity, KEY $"<SOURCE>" Contains "abc" can be written as KEY "abc".
The `Keycheck` block is especially handy in scenarios where a fixed set of strings is required for operations like data mapping, configuration settings, or any other list-specific tasks.

item.name: Base64ToBytes
item.introduction: The `Base64ToBytes` block converts a Base64 encoded string into an array of bytes. This is useful for decoding Base64 strings that represent binary data.

parameters.parameter: - "BASE64STRING" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The Base64 encoded string to be converted.
- [UrlEncoded?]: Optional. Specifies if the Base64 encoded string is URL encoded.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable where the byte array will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.
- [HIDDENVAR?]: Optional. When set to 'true', the resulting variable will be hidden.

notes.note: It is important to specify the correct encoding (UrlEncoded or not) to ensure accurate decoding.

item.name: BytesToBase64
item.introduction: The `BytesToBase64` block converts an array of bytes into a Base64 encoded string. This is useful for encoding binary data into a string format that can be easily transmitted or stored.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The byte array to be converted to Base64.
- [UrlEncoded?]: Optional. Specifies if the resulting Base64 string should be URL encoded.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable where the Base64 string will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [CHARSET_INPUT "encoding"]: If your input is a direct string, this parameter allows you to define the encoding of the string. The default encoding is UTF-8.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example:
BytesToBase64 "Hello World" -> VAR "ENCODED"
BytesToBase64 "Hello World" -> VAR "ENCODED" CHARSET_INPUT "utf-16"

notes.note: Ensure the input byte array is correctly formatted to avoid encoding errors.

item.name: Base64ToString
item.introduction: The `Base64ToString` block is used for converting a Base64 encoded string into its equivalent string representation. This is useful for decoding data which has been encoded using the Base64 algorithm.

parameters.parameter: - "BASE64" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The Base64 string to be converted.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable where the decoded string will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [CHARSET_INPUT "encoding"]: If your input is a direct string, this parameter allows you to define the encoding of the string. The default encoding is UTF-8.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the input Base64 string is correctly formatted to avoid decoding errors.

item.name: BigIntegerToBytes
item.introduction: The `BigIntegerToBytes` block is utilized for converting a BigInteger (a large integer) into a corresponding byte array. This conversion is essential in scenarios where large numeric values need to be represented in a byte format for processing or transmission.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The BigInteger value to be converted.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable where the resulting byte array will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [HIDDENVAR?]: Optional. When set to 'true', the resulting variable will be hidden.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the BigInteger value is within the acceptable range for conversion to avoid potential overflow errors.

item.name: BytesToBigInteger
item.introduction: The `BytesToBigInteger` block is designed to convert a byte array into a BigInteger, which is particularly useful when dealing with large numbers that cannot be represented using standard integer types.

parameters.parameter: - "BYTEARRAY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The byte array to be converted into a BigInteger.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable name where the resulting BigInteger will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [CHARSET_INPUT "encoding"]: If your input is a direct string, this parameter allows you to define the encoding of the string. The default encoding is UTF-8.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Be mindful of the size of the byte array to ensure it accurately represents the intended BigInteger value.

item.name: BinaryStringToBytes
item.introduction: The `BinaryStringToBytes` block is crafted to convert a binary string representation into a byte array. This functionality is crucial for handling data that is initially in a binary string format but needs to be processed as a byte array.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The binary string to be converted into a byte array.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable name where the resulting byte array will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the binary string is correctly formatted and contains only '0's and '1's. Incorrect formatting may result in unexpected conversion results.

item.name: BytesToBinaryString
item.introduction: The `BytesToBinaryString` block is designed to convert a byte array into its binary string representation. This is especially useful in scenarios where binary data needs to be represented in a readable and manageable string format.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The byte array to be converted into a binary string.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable name where the resulting binary string will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [CHARSET_INPUT "encoding"]: If your input is a direct string, this parameter allows you to define the encoding of the string. The default encoding is UTF-8.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It is essential to ensure that the byte array is properly formatted and contains valid binary data for correct conversion results.

item.name: HexToBytes
item.introduction: The `HexToBytes` block is used for converting a hexadecimal string into its corresponding byte array. This functionality is crucial for processing hexadecimal data often found in various encoding, cryptographic, and data processing tasks.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The hexadecimal string to be converted into a byte array.
- [HIDDENVAR?]: Optional. When set to 'true', the resulting variable will be hidden.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable name where the resulting byte array will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the hexadecimal string is valid and correctly formatted to avoid conversion errors.

item.name: BytesToHex
item.introduction: The `BytesToHex` block is designed for converting a byte array into a hexadecimal (hex) string. This is particularly useful for encoding binary data into a readable and transferable format.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The byte array to be converted into a hex string.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable name where the resulting hex string will be stored. If marked for capture (CAP), the variable is captured for subsequent use.
