- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Indexing is zero-based; the first character of the string is at index 0.
If the index is outside the bounds of the string, an error may occur.

item.name: RemoveString
item.introduction: The `RemoveString` block removes characters from a specified position in a string.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string from which characters are removed.
- STARTINDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The starting index from where characters will be removed.
- [COUNT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Optional. The number of characters to remove. If not specified or less than 0, removes all characters from "START_INDEX" to the end.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the resultant string is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The 'STARTINDEX' is zero-based; the first character of the string is at index 0.
If 'COUNT' is less than 0 or not provided, the method removes all characters from 'STARTINDEX' to the end of the string.
If 'STARTINDEX' is outside the bounds of the string, an error may occur.

item.name: ToLowerCase
item.introduction: The `ToLowerCase` block is used to convert all letters in a string to lowercase.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string to be converted to lowercase.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the lowercase result is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: This block does not alter the original string; it only provides a lowercase version of it.

item.name: ToUpperCase
item.introduction: The `ToUpperCase` block is used to convert all letters in a string to uppercase.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string to be converted to uppercase.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the uppercase result is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: This block does not alter the original string; it only provides an uppercase version of it.

item.name: ToTitleCase
item.introduction: The `ToTitleCase` block is used to convert the first letter of each word in a string to uppercase, while keeping other letters lowercase.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string to be converted to title case.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the title case result is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: This block does not alter the original string; it only provides a title case version of it.

item.name: Translate
item.introduction: The `Translate` block is used to translate text within a string based on a defined dictionary of key-value pairs.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string to be translated.
- KEY "KEY": The key to be replaced in the input string.
- VALUE "VALUE": The value to replace the key with in the input string.
- [ReplaceOne?]: Optional. If set to 'true', only the first occurrence of the key will be replaced.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the translated result is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The block can handle multiple key-value pairs for translation within the same block.
If multiple keys match in the input string, all of them will be replaced unless 'ReplaceOne' is set to true.

item.name: Trim
item.introduction: The `Trim` block is used to remove any leading or trailing whitespace from a given string.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string from which to remove whitespace.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the trimmed string is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The block trims both leading and trailing spaces, but does not affect spaces within the string itself.

item.name: Unescape
item.introduction: The `Unescape` block is used to unescape characters in a string, converting escape sequences into their actual representations.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string containing escape sequences to be unescaped.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the unescaped string is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Useful for processing strings that contain escape sequences such as newlines (\n), tabs (\t), or other special characters.

item.name: UrlEncode
item.introduction: The `UrlEncode` block is used for encoding a string into a format that is safe and valid for use within a URL.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string to be URL encoded.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the URL encoded string is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Useful for preparing strings for web requests where special characters need to be encoded.
Handles large strings by splitting them into chunks to avoid exceeding URL length limits.

item.name: UrlDecode
item.introduction: The `UrlDecode` block is used for decoding a URL-encoded string back to its original format.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL-encoded string to be decoded.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the decoded string is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Useful for decoding URL-encoded strings received from web requests or other sources.
Ensures that special characters in the URL are correctly interpreted.

item.name: CurrentUnixTime
item.introduction: The `CurrentUnixTime` block retrieves the current Unix time, which is the number of seconds (or milliseconds) that have elapsed since January 1, 1970, at 00:00:00 UTC.

parameters.parameter: - "TimeUnit": Specifies the unit of Unix time ('Seconds' or 'Milliseconds').
- [UseUtc?]: Optional. If 'true', uses UTC time; otherwise, local time is used.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the Unix time is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Unix time is widely used in programming and systems to record and compare points in time.
If 'UseUtc' is set to 'true', the block will ignore the local time zone and use UTC time instead.

item.name: CurrentDateTime
item.introduction: The `CurrentDateTime` block retrieves the current date and time, formatted based on a user-defined format.

parameters.parameter: - "FORMAT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The format in which the current date and time should be returned. It uses standard date and time format strings.
- [UseUtc?]: Optional. If 'true', uses UTC time; otherwise, local time is used.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the formatted date and time is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The format string must be a valid .NET date and time format string.
Consider the local time zone versus UTC time based on the 'UseUtc' parameter.

item.name: DateToUnixTime
item.introduction: The `DateToUnixTime` block converts a formatted datetime string to Unix time.

parameters.parameter: - "DATETIME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The datetime string to be converted to Unix time.
- "FORMAT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The format of the datetime string. For example: yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss,fff.
- [TimeUnit]: Optional. Specifies the unit of the Unix time (e.g., Seconds, Milliseconds).
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the Unix time is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the datetime format matches the format specified in the block.
Unix time can be in seconds or milliseconds based on the 'TimeUnit' parameter.

item.name: UnixTimeToDate
item.introduction: The `UnixTimeToDate` block converts Unix time to a formatted datetime string. This is useful for converting timestamps into human-readable date and time formats.

parameters.parameter: - "INPUT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The Unix time to be converted.
- "FORMAT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The format for the output datetime string, e.g., 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss,fff'.
- [From]: Optional. The unit of Unix time, such as 'Seconds' or 'Milliseconds'.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the formatted date and time is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Unix Time is measured in seconds or milliseconds since January 1, 1970 (UTC).
The 'FORMAT' parameter should be compatible with .NET's DateTime format specifiers.
If '[From]' is not specified, 'Seconds' is assumed by default.

item.name: UnixTimeToISO8601
item.introduction: The `UnixTimeToISO8601` block converts Unix time to an ISO8601 datetime string. This format is widely used for international date and time representations.

parameters.parameter: - INPUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The Unix time to be converted. Can be a number or string representing the time.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the ISO8601 formatted date and time is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Unix Time is the number of seconds that have elapsed since January 1, 1970 (midnight UTC/GMT), not counting leap seconds.
ISO8601 format is recognized internationally and used in computing environments and protocols.

item.name: DateToSolar
item.introduction: The `DateToSolar` block converts a Gregorian date to a Solar date. It is useful for applications needing date conversions to the Solar (Persian) calendar.

parameters.parameter: - "DATETIME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The Gregorian date to be converted. It should be a string in a recognizable date format.
- "FORMAT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The format of the input datetime string. Example format: 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss,fff'.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the Solar date is stored. 'VAR' for a regular variable, 'CAP' for a captured variable.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The Solar (Persian) calendar is widely used in several countries and is different from the Gregorian calendar.
Ensure the input date format matches the specified format string for accurate conversion.

item.name: CalcDateTimeDiff
item.introduction: The `CalcDateTimeDiff` block calculates the difference between two datetime values. It's useful for determining time spans, intervals, and durations between dates.

parameters.parameter: - "FIRST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The first datetime value in a specific format.
- "SECOND" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The second datetime value to compare against the first.
- "FORMAT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The format for the output time difference. Example format: 'd'd'.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the datetime difference is stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the datetime formats of the first and second values match for accurate calculation.
The format string should be designed based on the desired granularity of the time difference (e.g., days, hours, minutes).

item.name: CalcRelativeTime
item.introduction: The `CalcRelativeTime` block calculates the relative date for a given datetime that is older than the current date. It's useful for showing human-readable time differences, such as "3 days ago" or "one month ago".

parameters.parameter: - "FIRST" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The reference datetime to compare against.
- "SECOND" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The datetime string to calculate the relative date from.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the result is stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The block is designed to handle dates older than the current date and provides a human-friendly relative time format.
Ensure that the datetime formats are consistent for accurate calculation.

item.name: RandomUserAgent
item.introduction: The `RandomUserAgent` block generates a random user agent string. This can be useful for web scraping or other tasks where simulating browser requests is necessary.

parameters.parameter: - [PLATFORM]: Specifies the platform for which the user agent is generated (e.g., Windows, Android). Default is 'All'.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the generated user agent string is stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The generated user agent strings are random and can represent various browsers and operating systems.
Using random user agents can help prevent detection when scraping websites.

item.name: GenerateGuid
item.introduction: The `GenerateGuid` block creates a new Globally Unique Identifier (GUID). A GUID is a 128-bit integer used to uniquely identify information in software development.

parameters.parameter: - "FORMAT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the format for the GUID. Default is 'D'.
- [UpperCase?]: Optional. If set, the GUID will be in uppercase letters.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the generated GUID is stored.

notes.note: The 'D' format includes hyphens, while 'N' format is a 32-character hexadecimal number.

item.name: PhoneNumberCountryID
item.introduction: The `PhoneNumberCountryID` block identifies the country's name or its code based on a provided phone number. It uses international phone number standards to determine the associated country.

parameters.parameter: - "PHONENUMBER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The phone number to identify the country for.
- [CountryCodeOnly?]: Optional. If set, only the country code is returned (e.g., '1' for US). Otherwise, the country's name along with its code is returned (e.g., 'US (1)').
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the result is stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The phone number must be in international format (prefixed with '+').

item.name: Parse
item.introduction: The `Parse` block is designed to extract specific data from a given string using various parsing methods. Depending on the method chosen, you can specify the exact criteria for parsing, such as using left and right boundaries, CSS selectors, JSON fields, or regular expressions. The parsed data can then be stored in a variable or captured for further use.
item.syntax:
Parse "TARGET" LR "LEFT" "RIGHT" [Recursive?] [EncodeOutput?] [CreateEmpty?] [UseRegexLR?] -> VAR/CAP "NAME" ["PREFIX" "SUFFIX"]
Parse "TARGET" CSS "SELECTOR" "ATTRIBUTE" [INDEX / Recursive?] [EncodeOutput?] [CreateEmpty?] -> VAR/CAP "NAME" ["PREFIX" "SUFFIX
Parse "TARGET" JSON "FIELD" [JTokenParsing?] [Recursive?] [EncodeOutput?] [CreateEmpty?] -> VAR/CAP "NAME" ["PREFIX" "SUFFIX"]
Parse "TARGET" REGEX "REGEX" "OUTPUT" [Recursive?] [EncodeOutput?] [CreateEmpty?] [DotMatches?] [CaseSensitive?] -> VAR/CAP "NAME" ["PREFIX" "SUFFIX"]
Parse "TARGET" XPATH "EXPRESSION" "ATTRIBUTENAME" [Recursive?] [ElementIndex?] -> VAR/CAP "NAME" ["PREFIX" "SUFFIX"]

parameters.parameter: - "TARGET" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string or variable containing the data to be parsed.
- LR "LEFT" "RIGHT": Defines the left and right boundaries for parsing. Used in Left/Right parsing method.
- CSS "SELECTOR" "ATTRIBUTE": Uses a CSS selector and attribute for parsing. Used in CSS parsing method.
- JSON "FIELD": Specifies the JSON field to be parsed. Used in JSON parsing method.
- REGEX "REGEX" "OUTPUT": Defines the regular expression and output format for parsing. Used in Regex parsing method.
- XPATH "EXPRESSION" "ATTRIBUTENAME": Uses an XPath expression and attribute name for parsing. Used in XPath parsing method.
- [Recursive?]: Optional parameter to enable recursive parsing.
- [EncodeOutput?]: Optional parameter to encode the output of the parsing.
- [CreateEmpty?]: Optional parameter to create an empty variable even if no match is found.
- [ElementIndex]: The index of the desired element when the selector matches multiple elements.
- [DotMatches?]: Determines whether Regex '.' matches over multiple lines. Accepts 'True' or 'False'.
- [CaseSensitive?]: Determines whether Regex matches are case sensitive. Accepts 'True' or 'False'.
- [UseRegexLR?]: Determines whether to use a regex pattern to match text between two strings instead of the standard algorithm. Accepts 'True' or 'False'.

- [JTokenParsing?]: An optional parameter that, if set to 'True', enables parsing the JSON object using JToken paths. This allows for more advanced and precise JSON parsing capabilities, particularly useful when dealing with complex JSON structures.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": Defines the variable or capture name for storing the parsed data.
- ["PREFIX" "SUFFIX"]: Optional parameters to add a prefix or suffix to the parsed data.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.exmaple: Parse $"" LR "" "" Recursive=True -> CAP "BALANCE" "$" "" Parse $"" CSS "[name=csrf]" "value" -> VAR "CSRF"

item.name: LambdaParser
item.introduction: The `LambdaParser` block serves as a runtime parser for string expressions, including formulas and method calls. It dynamically builds a LINQ expression tree and compiles it into a lambda delegate for execution.

parameters.parameter: - "EXPRESSION" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The string expression to parse and evaluate.
- "VARCON" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the context variables for the expression.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the result is stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example: LambdaParser "a + b" -> VAR "result" VARCON "a: hello" VARCON "b: world"

notes.note: The parser supports dynamic variable contexts and allows for the execution of complex expressions.
In safe mode, the parser applies stricter rules for null comparison, similar to SQL.

section.item:
• Introduction:
The Script block is designed for invoking scripts in different languages. It allows for passing variables to the script and receiving results back. This block primarily serves as a way to integrate SvbScript code for readonly visualization and execution within the system.
BEGIN SCRIPT
END SCRIPT
• Notes:
Ensure that the script syntax and structure are correct as per the language specifications.

item.name: ShellCommand
item.introduction: The `ShellCommand` block executes a specified shell command and redirects the standard output (stdout) to an output variable.

parameters.parameter: - "EXECUTABLE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The executable or command to run.
- "ARGUMENTS" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Arguments to pass to the executable.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the result is stored.
- "CHARSET_OUT": Specifies the encoding for the output. Default is UTF8.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the command and arguments are secure and trusted, as shell commands can affect system security.

item.name: NativeLibInvoke
item.introduction: The `NativeLibInvoke` block dynamically invokes commands from native libraries (DLLs), allowing the integration of functions from languages like C++.

parameters.parameter: - "LIBPATH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Path to the native library file (DLL).
- "FUNCTIONNAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Name of the function to invoke from the DLL.
- "RETURNTYPE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The expected return type of the function.
- [Unload?]: Unloads the library after execution if set to true.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the result is stored.
- [PARAM "PARAMETER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Parameters to pass to the invoked function.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the library path and function calls are secure to avoid potential security risks.
Using native libraries requires understanding of the DLL and its functions.
Setting 'Unload' to true helps in managing memory and resources efficiently.

item.name: SolveTextCaptcha
item.introduction: The `SolveTextCaptcha` block is designed to solve text captchas by analyzing and interpreting the question provided.

parameters.parameter: - "QUESTION" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The text of the captcha question to solve.
- [LANGUAGEGROUP]: Optional. The language group of the captcha (e.g., Latin, Cyrillic).
- [LANGUAGE]: Optional. The specific language of the captcha (e.g., English, Spanish).
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable name where the solution will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Specifying the language group and language can improve accuracy.

item.name: SolveImageCaptcha
item.introduction: The `SolveImageCaptcha` block is designed to solve image-based captchas by analyzing and decoding the provided image in base64 format.

parameters.parameter: - "BASE64" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The base64 encoded string of the captcha image.
- [LANGUAGEGROUP]: Optional. The language group of the captcha (e.g., Latin, Cyrillic).
- [LANGUAGE]: Optional. The specific language of the captcha (e.g., English, Spanish).
- [CHARACTERSET]: Optional. The character set used in the captcha.
- [MINLENGTH]: Optional. The minimum length of the captcha solution.
- [MAXLENGTH]: Optional. The maximum length of the captcha solution.
- ["TEXTINSTRUCTIONS" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Optional. Additional text instructions for solving the captcha.
- [IsPhrase?]: Optional. Indicates if the captcha is a phrase.
- [CaseSensitive?]: Optional. Indicates if the captcha is case sensitive.
- [RequiresCalculation?]: Optional. Indicates if the captcha requires calculation.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable name where the solution will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example: SolveImageCaptcha "data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgo..." Latin English OnlyNumbers 5 10 "Enter numbers only" CaseSensitive=True -> VAR "Solution"]

notes.note: Ensure that the base64 image is properly formatted and readable for accurate results.
Specifying language, character set, and length constraints can improve accuracy.
Using text instructions can provide additional context or guidance for solving complex captchas.

item.name: SolveFunCaptcha
item.introduction: The `SolveFunCaptcha` block is used to automate the process of solving FunCaptcha challenges, a popular captcha system used on various websites.

parameters.parameter: - "PUBLICKEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The public key for the FunCaptcha challenge.
- "SERVICEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL to the service where the FunCaptcha is located.
- "SITEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the site where the FunCaptcha challenge appears.
- [NoJs?]: Optional. Indicates whether JavaScript is disabled.
- [UseProxy?]: Optional. Indicates whether to use a proxy for solving the challenge.
- [USER-AGENT ""]: Optional. The user agent to be used for the captcha solving process.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the solution of the FunCaptcha.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the public key, service URL, and site URL are correctly identified for effective solving.
Using the correct user agent helps in mimicking a real user and can improve the success rate.

item.name: SolveRecaptchaV2
item.introduction: The `SolveRecaptchaV2` block is designed to automate the solution of ReCaptcha V2 challenges, commonly used to verify human users on websites.

parameters.parameter: - "SITEKEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The site key for the ReCaptcha V2 challenge.
- "SITEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the site where the ReCaptcha challenge appears.
- "SDATA" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Optional additional data required for solving the ReCaptcha.
- [Enterprise?]: Indicates if the ReCaptcha is an enterprise version.
- [IsInvisible?]: Indicates if the ReCaptcha is an invisible version.
- [UseProxy?]: Optional. Indicates whether to use a proxy for solving the challenge.
- [USER-AGENT ""]: Optional. The user agent to be used during the captcha solving process.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the solution of the ReCaptcha.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure accurate input of the site key and URL for effective solving.
Consider using a user agent that matches the target site's expected audience to improve the success rate.

item.name: SolveRecaptchaV3
item.introduction: The `SolveRecaptchaV3` block is specifically designed to solve ReCaptcha V3 challenges, which are typically used to validate users without direct interaction.

parameters.parameter: - "SITEKEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The site key for the ReCaptcha V3 challenge.
- "SITEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the site where the ReCaptcha is located.
- "ACTION" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The action associated with the ReCaptcha challenge.
- [MINSCORE] / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The minimum score for the ReCaptcha challenge to be considered successful.
- [Enterprise?]: Indicates if the ReCaptcha is an enterprise version.
- [UseProxy?]: Optional. Indicates whether to use a proxy for solving the challenge.
- [USER-AGENT ""]: Optional. The user agent to be used during the captcha solving process.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the solution of the ReCaptcha.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure accurate input of the site key, URL, and action for effective solving.
The minimum score should be set according to the website's requirements.

item.name: SolveHCaptcha
item.introduction: The `SolveHCaptcha` block specializes in solving HCaptcha challenges, which are commonly used on websites as an alternative to ReCaptcha for bot protection.

parameters.parameter: - "SITEKEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The site key for the HCaptcha challenge.
- "SITEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the site where the HCaptcha is located.
- [UseProxy?]: Optional. Indicates whether to use a proxy for solving the challenge.
- [USER-AGENT ""]: Optional. The user agent to be used during the captcha solving process.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the solution of the HCaptcha.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure accurate input of the site key and URL for effective solving.

item.name: SolveKeyCaptcha
item.introduction: The `SolveKeyCaptcha` block is designed to automatically solve KeyCaptcha challenges, a type of captcha commonly used for website security and bot detection.

parameters.parameter: - "USERID" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The user ID associated with the KeyCaptcha challenge.
- "SESSIONID" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The session ID of the KeyCaptcha challenge.
- "WEBSERVERSIGN1" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The first web server sign key for the KeyCaptcha.
- "WEBSERVERSIGN2" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The second web server sign key for the KeyCaptcha.
- "SITEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the site where the KeyCaptcha is presented.
- [UseProxy?]: Optional. Specifies whether to use a proxy for solving the captcha.
- [USER-AGENT ""]: Optional. The user agent to be used during the captcha solving process.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the solution of the KeyCaptcha.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Accuracy in providing the KeyCaptcha parameters is crucial for successful solving.

item.name: SolveGeeTestCaptcha
item.introduction: The `SolveGeeTestCaptcha` block is used to automate the process of solving GeeTest captchas, a popular captcha format for website verification.

parameters.parameter: - "GT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The GT key associated with the GeeTest captcha.
- "APICHALLENGE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The API challenge key for the GeeTest captcha.
- "APISERVER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The API server address for the GeeTest captcha.
- "SITEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the website where the GeeTest captcha is implemented.
- [UseProxy?]: Optional. Indicates if a proxy should be used for solving the captcha.
- [USER-AGENT ""]: Optional. The user agent to be used during the captcha solving process.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the solution of the GeeTest captcha will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Accuracy in providing the GeeTest parameters is essential for successful captcha solving.

item.name: SolveCapyCaptcha
item.introduction: The `SolveCapyCaptcha` block is designed to facilitate the automatic solving of Capy captchas, a sophisticated captcha system that presents unique challenges to distinguish humans from automated bots.

parameters.parameter: - "SITEKEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique site key provided by Capy for captcha integration.
- "SITEURL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the website where the Capy captcha is located.
- [UseProxy?]: Optional. Specifies whether to use a proxy for solving the captcha.
- [USER-AGENT ""]: Optional. The user agent to be used during the captcha solving process.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the solution of the Capy captcha.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Accurate site key and URL are essential for the successful solving of Capy captchas.

item.name: ReportLastSolution
item.introduction: The `ReportLastSolution` block is designed to report an incorrect or inadequate captcha solution back to the captcha solving service. This is crucial in scenarios where the provided solution does not meet the required standards, potentially leading to refunds or credits.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Reporting inaccurate captcha solutions can help improve the service's accuracy over time.

item.name: OCR
item.introduction: The `OCR` block performs Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to extract text from images. It's essential for automating tasks that involve reading text from images.
item.syntax: OCR "LANGUAGE" [HttpLib] "CAPTCHA" -> [CAP|VAR] "NAME" [COOKIE "abc: def"]* [HEADER "abc: def"]* [FILTER "filter"]* [KEY "key" VALUE "value"]* [REGEX_REPLACE "pattern"] [REGEX_REPLACEMENT "replacement"] [REGEX_OPTIONS options] [ENGINE mode] [PAGESEG mode] [PIXELFORMAT format] [SECPROTO protocol] [PROXY usage] [TIMEOUT milliseconds] [SAFE?]

parameters.parameter: - "LANGUAGE": Language used for OCR, matching the text in the image.
- "CAPTCHA": The captcha image in Base64 format or a URL.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": Variable name for storing OCR results.
- "COOKIE": Custom cookies for HTTP requests.
- "HEADER": Custom headers for HTTP requests.
- "FILTER": Image filters to enhance OCR accuracy.
- "KEY" and "VALUE": Custom key-value pairs for translation or replacement.
- "REGEX_REPLACE": Regex pattern for text replacement.
- "REGEX_REPLACEMENT": Replacement text for regex match.
- "REGEX_OPTIONS": Options for regex operations.
- "ENGINE": OCR engine mode (e.g., Tesseract, LSTM).
- "PAGESEG": Page segmentation mode for OCR processing.
- "PIXELFORMAT": Image pixel format for processing.
- "SECPROTO": Security protocol for HTTP requests (e.g., TLS1.2).
- "PROXY": Proxy settings for network requests.
- "TIMEOUT": Request timeout in milliseconds.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

filters.filter: - Resize: Resizes the image to the specified width and height.
- InterpolativeResize: Resizes the image using a specific interpolation method.
- AdaptiveResize: Resizes the image adaptively to improve clarity and details.
- Resample: Resamples the image at a specified resolution.
- AdaptiveSharpen: Sharpens the image adaptively based on image content.
- Morphology: Applies morphological transformations such as dilation.
- AdaptiveThreshold: Determines and applies a threshold adaptively on image.
- Threshold: Applies a fixed threshold to the image.
- AutoThreshold: Automatically determines and applies a threshold.
- BlackThreshold: Converts pixels below a certain threshold to black.
- Rotate: Rotates the image by a specified degree.
- ReduceNoise: Reduces noise within the image.
- Despeckle: Removes speckle noise from the image.
- AdaptiveBlur: Blurs the image adaptively.
- MotionBlur: Applies a motion blur effect.
- RotationalBlur: Applies a rotational blur effect.
- SelectiveBlur: Blurs specific areas of the image.
- Blur: Applies a general blur effect to the image.
- Contrast: Enhances the contrast of the image.
- InverseContrast: Applies inverse contrast to the image.
- InverseSigmoidalContrast: Applies an inverse sigmoidal contrast adjustment.
- ContrastStretch: Stretches the image contrast.
- BrightnessContrast: Adjusts the brightness and contrast of the image.
- Crop: Crops the image to specified dimensions.
- Flip: Flips the image vertically.
- Flop: Flips the image horizontally.
- FloodFill: Fills a region with a specified color.
- Grayscale: Converts the image to grayscale.
- NegateGrayscale: Negates the grayscale of the image.
- Negate: Negates the colors of the image.
- CycleColormap: Cycles the colormap of the image.
- ChopVertical: Chops the image vertically.
- Roll: Rolls the image horizontally or vertically.
- Alpha: Sets the alpha channel of the image.
- AutoGamma: Automatically adjusts gamma of the image.
- BilateralBlur: Applies a bilateral blur to the image.
- AutoOrient: Automatically corrects the orientation of the image.
- BlueShift: Applies a blue shift effect to the image.
- Charcoal: Applies a charcoal sketch effect to the image.
- ChopHorizontal: Chops the image horizontally.
- Extent: Extends the image canvas.
- Deskew: Corrects skew in the image.
- Edge: Highlights edges in the image.
- Emboss: Applies an emboss effect to the image.
- Enhance: Enhances the quality of the image.
- Equalize: Equalizes the histogram of the image.
- Frame: Adds a frame around the image.
- Fx: Applies an FX expression to the image.
- HoughLine: Detects lines in the image using the Hough transform.
- Implode: Creates an implode effect on the image.
- Kuwahara: Applies the Kuwahara filter for edge-preserving smoothing.
- LiquidRescale: Rescales the image non-linearly.
- Lower: Creates a 3D effect on the image.
- Magnify: Magnifies a portion of the image.
- Minify: Minifies the image.
- Modulate: Modulates the brightness, saturation, and hue of the image.
- Normalize: Normalizes the pixel values in the image.
- OilPaint: Applies an oil painting effect to the image.
- Solarize: Applies a solarization effect to the image.
- Transparent: Makes a specified color in the image transparent.
- ColorFuzz: Adds fuzziness to the color in the image.

item.example: OCR eng B64"base64Image" -> VAR "extractedText" ENGINE TesseractOnly PAGESEG Auto FILTER "Resize(0, 0)" FILTER "Grayscale()"

notes.note: Proper image filtering can significantly enhance OCR accuracy.
Choosing the right OCR engine and settings is crucial for optimal results.
Network-related parameters (SECPROTO, PROXY) are essential for remote image fetching.

item.name: CloudflareBypass
item.introduction: The `CFBypass` block is designed for bypassing Cloudflare protection using flaresolverr.exe, specifically tailored for single-threaded operations. It facilitates navigation through Cloudflare's anti-bot challenges to access the desired web content.

parameters.parameter: - "API" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL where flaresolverr.exe is running.
- [METHOD]: The HTTP method (GET, POST) to use for the request.
- "URL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The target website URL protected by Cloudflare.
- [TIMEOUT]: Specifies the maximum time to wait for the request to complete.
- [ReadResponseContent?]: If set, reads and stores the response content. If not, skips reading the response.
- VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable to store the results.
- [CONTENT]: (Optional) Data sent in the body of a POST request.
- [CONTENTTYPE]: (Optional) The MIME type of the content being sent in a POST request.
- [PROXY]: (Optional) The proxy URL to be used by flaresolverr.exe.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure flaresolverr.exe is running and accessible at the specified API URL.

item.link: For Flaresolverr download and more information, visit: https://github.com/FlareSolverr/FlareSolverr

item.name: DestroyCFBypass
item.introduction: The `DestroyCFBypass` block is designed to terminate an ongoing Cloudflare bypass session initiated by flaresolverr.exe. It's crucial for managing and releasing resources associated with the session.

parameters.parameter: - "API" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL of the flaresolverr API where the session is being managed.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Make sure to use the same API URL as used in the `CFBypass` block to ensure the correct session is terminated.
Regularly destroying unused sessions helps maintain optimal performance and resource utilization.

item.name: OpenBrowser
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerOpenBrowser` block is responsible for initiating a new Puppeteer browser instance. It offers various configurations to tailor the browser environment according to the automation needs.

parameters.parameter: - ["ExtraCmdLineArgs" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: Additional command line arguments to be passed to the browser on startup.
- [StartMaximized?]: (Optional) Starts the browser maximized if set to true.
- [StartFullScreen?]: (Optional) Starts the browser in fullscreen mode if set to true.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure Puppeteer and its dependencies are correctly installed and configured.
Proxy settings and headless mode can be configured via global settings or directly through command line arguments.

item.name: NewTab
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerNewTab` block is designed to open a new page in a new browser tab using Puppeteer. It allows for multi-tabbed browsing within the automation process.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Each new tab opened with this block will be independent of the others, allowing for parallel operations within the same browser instance.
It's important to manage tabs effectively to avoid excessive resource usage.

item.name: GoBack
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerGoBack` block is used to navigate the Puppeteer browser back to the previously visited page. This feature is useful in scenarios where navigation through browser history is required as part of the automation process.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Using the 'PuppeteerGoBack' block effectively requires tracking the navigation history to ensure the desired page is reached.
This block is particularly useful in web scraping and automated browsing tasks that involve multi-page navigation.

item.name: GoForward
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerGoForward` block is designed to navigate the Puppeteer browser forward to the next visited page. This is useful in workflows that require moving ahead in the browsing history as part of an automated process.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: This block is useful for scenarios where you need to re-visit a page that was navigated away from in the same browsing session.
Effective use of 'PuppeteerGoForward' depends on the navigation history maintained by the browser instance.

item.name: Reload
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerReload` block is designed to refresh or reload the current page in a Puppeteer-controlled browser. This can be particularly useful in scenarios where page content needs to be updated or if issues arise during page loading.

parameters.parameter: - [TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: (Optional) The maximum time to wait for the page to reload, in seconds.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Using the 'PuppeteerReload' block is equivalent to hitting the refresh button in a web browser.
The timeout parameter ensures that the reloading process doesn't hang indefinitely in case of page load issues.

item.name: Switch To Tab
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerSwitchToTab` block enables navigation between different tabs in a Puppeteer-controlled browser. It focuses on a specific tab based on its index in the array of open tabs.

parameters.parameter: - INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the tab to switch to. Indexing starts from 0 for the first tab.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the index specified corresponds to an existing tab. An index out of range will lead to an error.
Tab indices can change as new tabs are opened or existing ones are closed.

item.name: Close Tab
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerCloseTab` block is used to close the currently active tab in a Puppeteer-controlled browser. This action allows for better management of browser resources during automation tasks.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Closing the active tab will switch focus to the first tab if multiple tabs are open.
If the active tab is the only one open, this action may result in closing the browser itself.

item.name: Close Browser
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerCloseBrowser` block is designed to close an open Puppeteer browser. This is a crucial function for managing browser instances and resources in automation processes.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Use this block to ensure that all Puppeteer browser instances are properly closed after your automation tasks are completed.
Closing the browser releases resources and helps maintain optimal performance of your application.

item.name: Click
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerClick` block simulates a mouse click on a specified element within a Puppeteer browser session. It allows for interaction with web page elements, such as buttons, links, or any other clickable items.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the element (e.g., by ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER": The identifier of the element to be clicked.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element when multiple elements match the identifier. It is useful when dealing with lists or collections of elements.
- MOUSEBUTTON: The mouse button used for clicking (e.g., Left, Right, Middle).
- CLICKCOUNT: The number of times the element should be clicked.
- TIMEBETWEENCLICKS: The delay between each click, in milliseconds.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Proper identification of the element is crucial for the click action to be executed correctly.
Adjusting the click count and delay can simulate different user interactions with the element.

item.name: Exists
item.introduction: The `PuppeteerExists` block verifies the presence of an element on a web page using Puppeteer. It is used to determine whether a specific element, identified by various selectors, exists on the page and returns a boolean result.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the element (e.g., by ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER": The identifier of the element to check for existence.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element when multiple elements match the identifier. It is useful when dealing with lists or collections of elements.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable to store the boolean result indicating the element's existence.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It's important to select the correct method for finding the element to ensure the accuracy of the existence check.
The result stored in the variable can be used to make conditional decisions in subsequent blocks.

item.name: Get Attribute Value
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetAttributeValue' block in Puppeteer is designed to retrieve the value of a specified attribute from an HTML element on a webpage. It is useful for extracting information like link URLs, text content, or any custom attribute values present in web elements.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method used to locate the element (e.g., Id, Name, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The specific identifier for the element, corresponding to the chosen method.
- [INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: (Optional) The index of the element in case there are multiple matches.
- "ATTRIBUTENAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The name of the attribute whose value is to be retrieved.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the retrieved value will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Properly identifying the element is crucial for the accurate retrieval of attribute values.
Consider using unique identifiers to avoid ambiguity when multiple elements match the criteria.

item.name: Get Attribute Value All
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetAttributeValueAll' block is used in Puppeteer for extracting the values of a specific attribute from multiple elements on a webpage. This block is particularly useful when dealing with lists or collections of similar items on a page, allowing for bulk data extraction.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method used to locate the elements (e.g., Id, Name, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the elements, corresponding to the chosen method.
- "ATTRIBUTENAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The name of the attribute whose values are to be retrieved.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the retrieved values will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It is essential to accurately target elements to ensure the correct values are extracted.

item.name: Get Height
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetHeight' block is designed for Puppeteer automation, enabling the retrieval of an element's height in pixels. This is useful for dynamically understanding the size and layout of elements on a page, especially in responsive design scenarios or when dealing with dynamic content.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method for locating the element (e.g., Id, Class, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the element, corresponding to the selected method.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element when multiple elements match the identifier. It is useful when dealing with lists or collections of elements.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable in which the height value is stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the correct identification of the element to obtain an accurate height measurement.

item.name: Get Width
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetWidth' block is a Puppeteer-based functionality that provides the width of a specified web element in pixels. This block is particularly useful for obtaining dimensions of elements on a webpage, which can be crucial in tasks like web scraping, layout testing, and automated UI testing.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the element (e.g., Id, Class).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The specific identifier of the element to measure.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element when multiple elements match the identifier. It is useful when dealing with lists or collections of elements.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the width of the element.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Enables safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Accuracy of the width measurement depends on correct element selection.

item.name: Get Position X
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetPositionX' block is designed to retrieve the X coordinate (horizontal position) of a specified web element in pixels. This block is essential for tasks that require precise element positioning, such as UI testing, web scraping, and automated interactions with web pages.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the element (e.g., Id, Class, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The specific identifier of the element whose X coordinate is to be determined.
- INDEX: The index of the element when multiple elements match the identifier. It is useful when dealing with lists or collections of elements.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable to store the X coordinate of the element.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It's crucial to ensure the element is correctly identified to get an accurate X coordinate value.

item.name: Get Position Y
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetPositionY' block is specialized in obtaining the Y coordinate (vertical position) of an element on a webpage, measured in pixels. This block is essential for accurately determining the vertical positioning of elements for tasks like automated testing, web scraping, and interactive automation on web pages.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method used to locate the element (e.g., Class, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The specific identifier for the element whose Y coordinate is being sought.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element when multiple elements match the identifier. It is useful when dealing with lists or collections of elements.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable that will store the obtained Y coordinate of the element.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Enables safe mode for better error management.

notes.note: Accuracy in element identification is key to obtaining the correct Y coordinate.

item.name: Is Displayed
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerIsDisplayed' block checks whether a specified element is currently visible on a web page. It's essential for verifying the presence and visibility of elements in web automation and testing scenarios, ensuring that user interactions and data collection processes are aligned with the actual state of the web page.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method used to find the element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the target element whose display status is to be checked.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element when multiple elements match the identifier. It is useful when dealing with lists or collections of elements.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The variable where the boolean result (true if displayed, false otherwise) will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Accurate element identification is crucial for reliable display status checks.
This block is particularly useful in dynamic web pages where element visibility can change.

item.name: Screenshot Element
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerScreenshotElement' block captures a screenshot of a specified element in a Puppeteer-controlled browser. It's useful for visually verifying the state of web elements during automation tasks, debugging, or documentation purposes.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method for locating the element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the target element to be screenshotted.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element when there are multiple matches to the identifier, used to specify which element to capture.
- "FILENAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The path and name of the file where the screenshot will be saved.
- [FullPage?]: Optional. If set, captures the full page including off-screen parts.
- [OmitBackground?]: Optional. If set, omits the background for transparency in the screenshot.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the file path is correctly specified and accessible. The FullPage and OmitBackground options can significantly change the screenshot results.

item.name: Screenshot Element Base64
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerScreenshotBase64' block captures a screenshot of a specified Puppeteer element and converts it into a base64 string. This functionality is particularly useful for handling screenshots directly within the script without needing to save them as files.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method for finding the element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier of the element to be screenshotted.
- [INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The index of the element when multiple matches are found. Used to specify the exact element.
- [FullPage?]: Optional. Captures the full page if set, including off-screen content.
- [OmitBackground?]: Optional. Omits the background to make it transparent in the screenshot.
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable where the base64 string will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The base64 string can be used for inline display of images or for processing without needing external file storage.

item.name: Select
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSelect' block is used to select a specific value from a dropdown (select element) in a Puppeteer-controlled page. It's useful for automating interactions with forms and other UI elements where a selection is required.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method used to locate the select element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the select element to interact with.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element if there are multiple matches. Used to specify the exact element.
- "VALUE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The value to be selected from the dropdown menu.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: The name of the variable where the result of the selection will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example: PuppeteerSelect Class "form-control gds-cr" 0 "United States of America" -> VAR "selectedCountry"

notes.note: Ensure the specified value exists in the dropdown options; otherwise, the block may not function as expected.

item.name: Select By Index
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSelectByIndex' block allows you to select an option from a dropdown (select element) based on its index in a Puppeteer-controlled page. This is particularly useful for automating forms where the exact value may vary, but the position is consistent.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the select element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the select element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element if multiple matches are found.
- SELECTIONINDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the option within the select element to be selected.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: The name of the variable to store the result of the selection.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the index is within the range of available options in the dropdown.

item.name: Select By Text
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSelectByText' block is designed for selecting an option within a dropdown (select element) based on the displayed text in a Puppeteer-controlled web page. This is useful when you need to interact with dropdowns where the value is dynamic or unknown, but the text is predictable.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the select element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the select element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element if multiple matches are found.
- "TEXT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The text of the option to be selected in the select element.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: The name of the variable to store the result of the selection.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Verify the text matches exactly with the option's text in the dropdown.

item.name: Set Attribute Value
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSetAttributeValue' block is used for altering the value of a specified attribute of an element within a Puppeteer-controlled webpage. This functionality is essential for dynamically modifying page elements, such as changing styles, properties, or other attributes programmatically.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element if multiple matches are found.
- "ATTRIBUTENAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The name of the attribute to modify.
- "VALUE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The new value to set for the attribute.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the attribute name and value syntax is correct for the specific element being targeted.

item.name: Submit
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSubmit' block in Puppeteer scripts is used to submit a form element on a webpage. This is particularly useful for automating form submissions or triggering form-related events programmatically.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the form element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The identifier for the form element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the form element if multiple matches are found. Optional.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: Specifies whether the result should be stored in a variable or captured.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Use the 'PuppeteerSubmit' block for forms where the traditional 'click' event on a submit button does not trigger the desired action.

item.name: Switch To Frame
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSwitchToFrame' block is used in Puppeteer scripts to switch the context to a different iframe on a webpage. This is crucial for interacting with elements inside iframes, which are essentially embedded web pages within a web page.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to find the iframe element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier for the iframe element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index position of the iframe element if multiple elements are matched. This parameter is optional.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: After switching to an iframe, all subsequent commands will interact with elements within that iframe.

item.name: Type
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerTypeElement' block is designed to simulate typing text into input fields within a webpage using Puppeteer. This block is instrumental in automating data entry, form submissions, and interacting with web elements that require text input.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the input field (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier for the input element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the input element if multiple matches are found. Optional.
- "TEXT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The text to be typed into the input field.
- TIMEBETWEENKEYSTROKES / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The delay (in milliseconds) between individual keystrokes. Optional.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Setting a delay between keystrokes can mimic human typing more realistically.

item.name: Type Human
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerTypeElementHuman' block is used for typing text into input fields with human-like random delays, enhancing the realism of interactions in automated Puppeteer scripts. This block is particularly useful for mimicking human behavior in data entry and form submissions.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the input field (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier for the input element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the input element if multiple matches are found. Optional.
- "TEXT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The text to be typed into the input field.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: This block simulates typing with random delays between keystrokes to mimic human typing behavior.
Appropriate for scenarios where bot detection measures are in place.

item.name: Upload Files
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerUploadFiles' block enables the uploading of one or more files to a specified element in Puppeteer scripts. It is commonly used for handling file input fields in web forms and applications.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier for the element.
- INDEX / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The index of the element if multiple matches are found. Optional.
- [PATH "filePath" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The path(s) of the file(s) to be uploaded. Multiple paths can be specified.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the file paths are valid and accessible by the script.

item.name: Wait For Element
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerWaitForElement' block in Puppeteer scripts pauses the execution until a specified element appears on the page, making it essential for managing dynamic content or waiting for page loads.

parameters.parameter: - [FINDBY]: The method to locate the element (e.g., ID, Selector).
- "IDENTIFIER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The unique identifier of the element.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The maximum time to wait for the element (in milliseconds). Optional.
- [Hidden?]: Waits for the element to be hidden. Optional.
- [Visible?]: Waits for the element to be visible. Optional, default is true.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Setting both 'Hidden' and 'Visible' can lead to unpredictable behavior.
The block will throw an exception if the element does not appear within the specified timeout.

item.name: Navigate To
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerNavigateTo' block in Puppeteer scripts allows for navigation to a specific URL within the current page context. This block is fundamental for directing the browser to different web pages or resources.

parameters.parameter: - "URL" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The URL to navigate to.
- [LOADEDEVENT]: The event to wait for before considering navigation successful.
- "REFERER" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The referer header value.
- [TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The maximum time to wait for navigation to complete, in milliseconds. Optional.
- [BanOnTimeout?]: Specifies if the request should be marked as BAN on timeout. Optional.
- [HEADER "abc: def"]: Custom HTTP headers to send with the navigation request. Optional.

notes.note: Use the TIMEOUT parameter cautiously as setting it too low may cause incomplete page loads.
Custom headers are useful for authenticated requests or setting specific request properties.

item.name: Wait For Navigation
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerWaitForNavigation' block is utilized in Puppeteer scripts to pause script execution until the navigation of the current page is completed. This is crucial for ensuring that the page has fully loaded before proceeding with subsequent actions.

parameters.parameter: - [LOADEDEVENT]: The specific event to wait for before resuming script execution. Options include 'Load', 'DOMContentLoaded', 'Networkidle0', etc.
- TIMEOUT / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The maximum time to wait for the navigation to complete, specified in milliseconds. Default is 30000ms (30 seconds).
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Adjusting the TIMEOUT value may be necessary for pages with longer load times or heavy resources.
Using the correct LOADEDEVENT is important for accurate synchronization with page activities.

item.name: Get Cookies
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetCookies' block is designed to retrieve cookies for a specified domain from the browser in Puppeteer scripts. This block is essential for managing web session data and is commonly used in web scraping and automation processes.

parameters.parameter: - ["DOMAIN" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The domain for which cookies are to be retrieved. If empty, cookies for all domains are retrieved.
- [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: The name of the variable where the retrieved cookies will be stored. If marked for capture, cookies will be available for further processing.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the DOMAIN parameter accurately reflects the target domain to avoid inconsistencies in the retrieved cookie data.

item.name: Clear Cookies
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerClearCookies' block is designed to delete cookies stored for a specific website in Puppeteer scripts. This block is essential for managing web session data and is commonly used in scenarios requiring session reset or privacy control.

parameters.parameter: - "WEBSITE" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The website for which cookies are to be cleared. It specifies the domain of the cookies to delete.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the WEBSITE parameter accurately reflects the target domain to avoid unintentional deletion of cookies from other domains.

item.name: Set Cookies
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSetCookies' block is used to set specific cookies for a given domain within a Puppeteer-controlled browser page. This block is crucial for managing web sessions, testing scenarios involving cookies, and customizing user experiences based on cookie data.

parameters.parameter: - ["DOMAIN" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.]: The domain for which cookies are to be set. Defines the scope of the cookies.
- [COOKIE "abc: def"]: A list of cookies to be set for the domain. Each cookie is specified as a name-value pair.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Properly setting the DOMAIN parameter is essential to ensure the cookies are applied to the correct website or web application.

item.name: Set User-Agent
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSetUserAgent' block is designed to modify the user agent string of the browser page in Puppeteer. This is essential for testing websites across different browsers and devices, or for web scraping purposes where simulating a specific browser or device is necessary.

parameters.parameter: - "USER-AGENT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The user agent string to be set for the browser page. This string identifies the type of browser and operating system to the web server.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.example: PuppeteerSetUserAgent "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/58.0.3029.110 Safari/537.36"

notes.note: The User Agent string should be chosen carefully to ensure that it accurately represents the browser or device being simulated.

item.name: Set Captcha Solution
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSetCaptchaSolution' block allows the input of a captcha solution into a Puppeteer-managed webpage. This block is essential for bypassing captcha challenges during automated browsing or scraping activities.

parameters.parameter: - "SOLUTION" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The solution to the captcha challenge.
- [CAPTCHATYPE]: The type of captcha being solved (e.g., ReCaptchaV2, ReCaptchaV3).
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure the solution is correct and valid for the captcha type.

item.name: Get DOM
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerGetDOM' block is designed to retrieve the full Document Object Model (DOM) of a webpage as it is rendered in a Puppeteer-controlled browser. This block is invaluable for web scraping, data extraction, or analysis tasks where accessing the entire HTML structure of a page is necessary.

parameters.parameter: - [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: The variable where the DOM will be stored. This variable can be marked for capture if necessary.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the page has fully loaded before using this block to get an accurate representation of the DOM.
This block will capture the inner HTML of the body element, including all its child elements.
If the [VAR/CAP "NAME"] is left empty, storing the DOM in '<SOURCE>', which is a general variable.

item.name: Set Viewport
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSetViewport' block in Puppeteer scripts is crucial for defining the dimensions and settings of the viewport in a browser page. This block allows for customization of the viewport to simulate various device sizes and orientations, enhancing testing and scraping capabilities in different screen environments.

parameters.parameter: - "WIDTH" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The width of the viewport in pixels.
- "HEIGHT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The height of the viewport in pixels.
- ScaleFactor / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The device scale factor (zoom level).
- [IsMobile?]: Indicates if the viewport should simulate a mobile device.
- [IsLandscape?]: Indicates if the viewport should be in landscape orientation.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

item.name: Switch To Main Frame
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerSwitchToMainFrame' block in Puppeteer scripts is designed to switch the focus of the browser automation process to the main frame of a web page. This is essential when navigating through pages with multiple frames or iframes, ensuring that subsequent actions are performed within the context of the main document.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Useful in scenarios where an automated script navigates away from the main frame, such as interacting with iframes or pop-ups, and needs to return to the main content.

item.name: Key Press in Page
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerPageKeyPress' block in Puppeteer scripts is used to simulate the pressing and releasing of a specific key within the browser page. This functionality is crucial for automating interactions that require keyboard input, like filling out forms or navigating web applications.

parameters.parameter: - "KEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The key to be pressed and released. The value should be in string format and represent a valid key according to Puppeteer's keyboard API. A full list of keys can be found in the Puppeteer documentation (https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/blob/v1.14.0/lib/USKeyboardLayout.js).
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: It is essential to ensure that the key value matches one of the keys listed in the Puppeteer keyboard API documentation to avoid errors during script execution.
This block is useful for scenarios where keyboard interaction is required, such as form submissions, navigation, or executing specific commands on a web page.

item.name: Key Down in Page
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerPageKeyDown' block simulates pressing a key on the keyboard in a browser page without releasing it. This block is essential for automating tasks that require a key to be held down, such as initiating drag-and-drop actions or activating keyboard shortcuts in web applications.

parameters.parameter: - "KEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The key to be pressed down. The value should be a string that matches one of the keys in Puppeteer's keyboard API. Refer to Puppeteer documentation for a comprehensive list of supported keys (https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/blob/v1.14.0/lib/USKeyboardLayout.js).
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: The block is handy in scenarios that require sustained keyboard input, such as in gaming or advanced web interactions.

item.name: Key Up in Page
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerPageKeyUp' block is designed to simulate the release of a key that was previously pressed in the browser page. This block is critical for accurately replicating human-like interactions with web applications, such as typing, executing keyboard shortcuts, or concluding drag-and-drop actions.

parameters.parameter: - "KEY" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the key to be released. The value should correspond to a key in Puppeteer's keyboard API. For a complete list of key names supported by Puppeteer, refer to: https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/blob/v1.14.0/lib/USKeyboardLayout.js.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: This block is typically used in conjunction with 'PuppeteerPageKeyDown' to simulate complete key press actions.

item.name: Screenshot Page
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerScreenshotPage' block is instrumental in capturing screenshots of the entire browser page or its visible part. It's especially useful for debugging, archiving, or testing purposes, allowing users to save a visual representation of the page at a specific instance.

parameters.parameter: - "FILENAME" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the file path and name where the screenshot will be saved. The extension of the file determines the format of the screenshot (e.g., .png, .jpeg).
- [FullPage?]: When set to true, captures the entire page including the non-visible part. If false, only the visible part of the page is captured.
- [OmitBackground?]: When set to true, makes the background of the screenshot transparent (only applicable for .png format).
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: If 'FullPage' is set to false and 'OmitBackground' to true, only the visible part of the page will be captured with a transparent background.

item.name: Screenshot Page Base64
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerScreenshotPageBase64' block captures a screenshot of the current browser page and converts it into a Base64 encoded string. This is useful for storing or transmitting screenshots as text-based data.

parameters.parameter: - [FullPage?]: When set to true, captures the entire page including the non-visible part. If false, only the visible part of the page is captured.
- [OmitBackground?]: When set to true, makes the background of the screenshot transparent (only applicable for .png format).
- -> VAR/CAP "NAME": The name of the variable where the Base64 encoded string of the screenshot will be stored.
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: If 'OmitBackground' is set, the screenshot will have a transparent background, which is useful for overlaying the screenshot on different backgrounds.

item.name: Scroll By
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerScrollBy' block enables automated scrolling of the webpage in both horizontal and vertical directions. This is particularly useful in scenarios where content loading depends on scroll position or for simulating user scrolling behavior.

parameters.parameter: - HORIZONTALSCROLL / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the horizontal scroll amount in pixels. Positive values scroll right, negative values scroll left.
- VERTICALSCROLL / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: Specifies the vertical scroll amount in pixels. Positive values scroll down, negative values scroll up.

notes.note: The scrolling is relative to the current scroll position of the page. Repeated execution of this block can be used for continuous scrolling.
Ensure the scroll amounts are within the dimensions of the page to avoid scrolling beyond the page's content.

item.name: Scroll To Top
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerScrollToTop' block is designed to automatically scroll to the top of a webpage. This function is useful in scenarios where you need to return to the beginning of a page, especially after navigating or scrolling through long pages.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: This function might not work as expected on pages with dynamic content loading, where the top of the page is not defined by a fixed point.

item.name: Scroll To Bottom
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerScrollToBottom' block enables automatic scrolling to the bottom of a webpage. This is particularly useful for pages where content extends beyond the initial viewable area, necessitating scrolling to access additional information or elements located at the bottom.

parameters.parameter: - [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: On pages with dynamic or infinite scrolling, the 'PuppeteerScrollToBottom' function may need to be executed multiple times to reach the actual end of the page.

item.name: Type in Page
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerPageType' block is designed to simulate typing text into the active browser page. It is useful for automating actions like entering text in search fields or forms on a webpage.

parameters.parameter: - "TEXT" / $"variable" / CS"code" / etc.: The text that will be typed into the page. This parameter accepts both constant and variable types
- [SAFE?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.

notes.note: Ensure that the focus is set on the correct element before using this block, as it types where the cursor is currently active.
This block does not clear previous text in a field; use a combination of keystrokes (like Ctrl+A and Delete) to clear fields if needed before typing.

item.name: Execute Func
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerExecuteFunc' block executes a JavaScript function within the context of the current page in a Puppeteer-controlled browser. It can be used to interact with the page's DOM or execute any JS script and returns a JSON response.

parameters.parameter: - [-> VAR/CAP "NAME"]: The name of the variable where the result of the JS function will be stored.
- [SafeMode?]: Optional. Activates safe mode for error handling.
- [ARG "argument"]: Arguments that can be passed to the JavaScript code. These are optional and can be used multiple times.

notes.note: The function can return a value, which will be converted to a JSON string.

item.name: Execute Js
item.introduction: The 'PuppeteerExecuteJs' block evaluates a JavaScript expression within the context of the current page in a Puppeteer-controlled browser. It allows for dynamic interaction with the page's content and functionality, returning a JSON response of the execution result.
